This approach involves using the patient's own cells to treat their cancer. The cells used for this study are immune cells known as dendritic cells. Dendritic cells are found in the immune system and help the body to fight infection. They are one of the body's defences against cancer. 

Dendritic cells can be made from a patient's own immune cells. They can then be activated to make them better at fighting cancer. They are also given a substance called granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). This helps them grow and mature. This process is known as ex vivo expansion. This means that the cells are grown outside of the body in a laboratory. 

After the dendritic cells have been activated and expanded, they are injected back into the patient. The idea is that these activated and expanded dendritic cells will help to fight the patient's cancer. Additionally, the GM-CSF stimulates the production of antiviral and anti-tumour substances, which may help to boost the immune system. 

This approach has already been successful in treating a variety of different cancers, including melanoma, lymphoma, and leukaemia. However, there is still a lot of research needed to determine the optimal way to use DC-GM-CSF therapy in treating prostate cancer. In this study, we will evaluate the safety and efficacy of this therapy in patients with prostate cancer.

We will also use a variety of advanced imaging and laboratory techniques to better understand how the dendritic cells interact with the patient's immune system. This information will help us to improve the design and delivery of future DC-GM-CSF therapies. 

Overall, this study will provide valuable information about the use of DC-GM-CSF therapy in the treatment of prostate cancer. We hope that this approach will lead to new and effective treatments for this disease. 

If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact us. 

Thank you for your interest in this research study.

Abstract:
Objective: The aim of this study was to estimate the incidence of acute pancreatitis in patients operated for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Summary Background Data: Postoperative acute pancreatitis is a well‐known complication after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. However, some authors consider the association between pancreas traction and the appearance of this complication. Methods: In a prospective study conducted at a single hospital over a 6‐year period we studied a group of 1522 patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy in which all patients underwent the same standard technique, including traction of the duodenopancreatic loop and subhepatic cholecystectomy. All the patients had been monitored postoperatively for at least 5 days while the clinical, laboratory and imaging features for the early diagnosis of acute pancreatitis were documented. Results: Postoperative acute pancreatitis was confirmed in two patients (1.3%) and it was severe in one. Conclusions: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is safe and free from postoperative acute pancreatitis.

Abstract:
Background: This study was designed to determine and compare the effects of 1% propofol and 1% propofol‐based remifentanil bolus‐infusion on hemodynamic stability and recovery of spontaneous ventilation after induction of anesthesia in ASA physical status I‐III patients scheduled for upper abdominal or head and neck surgery. Methods: Ninety patients were allocated randomly into two groups according to the anesthetic induction techniques used. Group P (n=45) was inducted with propofol and group R (n=45) with propofol‐based remifentanil bolus‐infusion. Hemodynamic changes, recovery of spontaneous ventilation (SO295%) defined as SO 95% and the need for atropine for postoperative bradycardia were compared between the two groups. Results: SO295% was 7.2±3.1 minutes in group P and 5.1±3.3 minutes in group R (p=0.02); the time in which the minimum heart rate was reached was 40.2±26.1 seconds in group P and 3.5±2.0 seconds in group R (p=0.03). Conclusion: In conclusion, it appears that the 1% bolus‐infusion of propofol plus remifentanil provides a greater hemodynamic stability and faster recovery of spontaneous ventilation than 1% propofol alone.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with chronic pancreatitis are often treated endoscopically (endoscopic ultrasound-guided drainage for the treatment for pseudocyst, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)/papillotomy for the management of obstructive jaundice, endoscopic pancreatic sphincterotomy for pain management). Although these therapies are commonly used, their long-term outcomes are relatively unknown. To help assess the long-term outcomes of interventional endoscopic techniques for chronic pancreatitis, investigators have organized the North America Pancreatic Study Group (NAPSG) Registry. The NAPSG Registry is an ongoing research study that will follow patients with chronic pancreatitis who have undergone endoscopic interventions at approximately 30 medical centers across the United States. The purpose of this study is to explore the long-term clinical and radiologic outcomes of chronic pancreatitis, to determine when complications related to chronic pancreatitis develop, to identify risk factors that may contribute to their development, and to evaluate the efficacy of endoscopic interventions in the management of chronic pancreatitis and related complications.

Abstract:
Introduction: Although endoscopic ultrasound‐ guided transgastric endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (EUS‐Guided ERC) has been widely used for many years, there are few reports on EUS‐Guided ERC with large duodenal diverticulum (DD) cases. Herein, we first review 5 cases of EUS‐Guided ERC with large DDs. Case Presentation: For five patients, 26–38 year old (mean age, 30.3 years old) with DD and cholangitis, Ercp was performed by the EUS‐Guided method with DDs ranging in size between 5.8cm to 6.7cm. There was no intraoperative complication, such as bleeding and perforation. No patient developed pancreatitis after treatment, and no patient had DD or cholangitis recurrence during follow‐up. Discussion: The present study demonstrated that EUS‐Guided ERC had high safety and efficacy when performed for patients with large DDs. The procedure was well tolerated; however, it was still associated with a learning curve. Therefore, well training and understanding of relevant anatomy and technical skills (including fluoroscopy and pancreatic duct cannulation) are important for a safe and effective technique. Conclusions: For patients with DDs, careful preprocedural imaging and accurate diagnosis of the anatomy are necessary. EUS‐Guided ERC and pancreatic sphincterotomy can effectively deal with cholangitis, which offers a new method of treating refractory cholangitis, improving the prognosis of patients, and reducing the incidence of cholangitis recurrence.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The overall survival of patients with multiple myeloma (MM) is around 5 years, and relapse or refractory is the main cause of death after 3-6 3-month cycles of bortezomib and dexamethasone maintenance therapy (MT) after ASCT. In addition to MT after ASCT, there is still no established treatment regimen for patients with relapse or refractory. Lenalidomide is a new drug developed for the treatment of patients with MM who have relapsed or refractory or are refractory to therapy. Lenalidomide plus bortezomib and dexamethasone (LBd) has received orphan designation in the United States and the European Union (EU) for the treatment of MM. The study is a prospective, randomized controlled, multicenter, three-arm design, phase III study, in which patients with refractory and recurrent MM after 3-6 cycles of bortezomib and dexamethasone maintenance therapy after allogeneic stem cell transplantation (ASCT) are recruited and randomized to receive lenalidomide combined with dexamethasone or bortezomib and dexamethasone as first-line treatment for patients with refractory and recurrent multiple myeloma. Abstract:
We previously conducted a phase III, randomized, double‐masked, controlled trial of docetaxel and cisplatin with or without bevacizumab (BEV) in patients with unresectable Stage III NSCLC. A total of 419 patients were randomly assigned to receive cisplatin 80 mg/m2 with docetaxel (75 mg/m2) concurrently with BEV (10 mg/kg) or without BEV for six 21‐day cycles. The primary end point was progression‐free survival (PFS), and an independent review committee (IRC) assessed responses according to the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors. At data cutoff, the median PFS was 5.5 months and 4.2 months in the BEV and non‐BEV groups (hazard ratio 0.75; 95% confidence interval 0.56‐1.01; P=0.060). Overall survival (OS) and incidence of adverse events were comparable for both groups. The median IRC‐assessed PFS was 5.0 months and 4.2 months in the BEV and non‐BEV groups (hazard ratio 0.76; 95% confidence interval 0.56‐1.04; P=0.100), and the median IRC‐assessed OS was 14.8 months and 13.3 months in the BEV and non‐BEV groups (hazard ratio 1.09; 95% confidence interval 0.78‐1.55; P=0.604). Adverse events were consistent with chemotherapy reported previously. In conclusion, the addition of BEV to platinum‐based combination chemotherapy did not significantly prolong PFS based on results of both IRC and investigators in patients with unresectable Stage III NSCLC.

The aim of the study is to assess the level of inflammatory biomarkers in patients with diabetic macular oedema during the first two years of standard of care treatment (anti-VEGF) to see if there is a correlation with treatment response.

Abstract:
To describe experiences of men and women receiving androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) to treat prostate cancer. Methods: Participants from five US studies (two on prostate cancer, two on breast cancer, and one on infertility) were randomized to receive ADT with goserelin or leuprolide acetate. Men had had castrating doses of goserelin (3.6 mg/month) or leuprolide (7.5‐11.25 mg/month) during an open‐label phase of their respective trials. Women had had high or moderate doses of leuprolide for an average of 5 years. Data were collected by phone interviews (n=268). Data collected included demographics, history of chemotherapy, depression and sleep disorders, sexual function, psychosocial characteristics, and physical functioning. RESULTS: Patient experience with ADT differed by both cancer type and gender. Men receiving ADT reported feeling less sexually attractive, but less depressed and fatigued, than women receiving ADT. Men and women reported comparable impacts of treatment on libido but more men than women reported erectile dysfunction. Men reporting erectile dysfunction also were more likely to report a history of concurrent chemotherapy than men overall. Men were more likely than women to report that they had reduced or ceased their social activities and to report fatigue. Depression was identified as a common side effect of ADT, and it appeared to affect sexual functioning for men but not for women. CONCLUSIONS: A combination of behavioral and pharmacological interventions may address the problems faced by patients receiving ADT.

Brief Summary

This study is a prospective, interventional longitudinal, open phase 3 study designed to compare the efficacy of aflibercept treatment intervals (IVETs 2, 3, 4, 5, 8 and 18 weeks) with ranibizumab (IVETs 4, 8 and 12 weeks) based on visual acuity (VA) and central subfield thickness (CST) end points in people with diabetic macular edema (DME). Patients will have either received IVET 2 at random based on their most recent VA results; IVETs 4, 8 and 12 weeks based on their most recent VA results will be used as controls to the IVET 2 control group. Participants will either have 2 injections of 2mg aflibercept at their baseline visit and the second 1 month after for 5 injections aflibercept at 4, 8 and 12 weeks, 5 injections aflibercept at 3, 8, 12 and 18 weeks or 5 injections aflibercept at 8, 12 and 18 weeks after their baseline visit and the second 1 month after for 5 injections. Participants will receive a single injection of aflibercept as rescue therapy if their VA is deteriorating or CST increase is greater than or equal to 150 microns, despite the above specified treatment regimen will be discontinued 1 month later. All participants may enter an open-label extension phase. Approval by the Institutional Review Board (IRB)/Ethics Committee (EC) is required. Study duration is expected to be approximately 62 months.

Intervention

The addition of the kinase inhibitor nilotinib to imatinib at diagnosis. The current first line treatment of CML is imatinib. Nilotinib is a newer and more potent kinase inhibitor approved by the FDA for use in patients that fail to enter cytogenetic remission, become resistant to or intolerant of imatinib. The rationale for using nilotinib as a first line treatment for patients with newly diagnosed CML is based on evidence showing that adding nilotinib to imatinib induces rapid cytogenetic remission (RCR) and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with resistant or intolerant CML, as well as a higher rate of molecular remissions in imatinib-treated patients.

Brief Summary

The purpose of the study is to investigate the safety and efficacy of a novel drug formulation of Tofacitinib citrate 2.5 mg in the treatment of rosacea. The study is a 6 week, double-blinded, randomized placebo controlled clinical trial.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Phase 2a, multicenter, randomized (1:1) study to establish proof of pharmacological concept and support dose finding in patients with papulopustular rosacea. The primary objective of the planned study is to determine if Tofacitinib citrate 2.5 mg is efficacious in 6 weeks compared with placebo, as assessed based on the proportion of patients reaching a ≥2 point improvement in Investigator's Global Assessment score. The study will include 2 doses of Tofacitinib citrate 2.5 mg: Tofacitinib citrate 2.5 mg 400 mg BID and Tofacitinib citrate 6.25 mg 400 mg BID.

Methods: The MATP (Minimum‐dose Aspirin in the Transdermal Patch) study was a prospective, randomized, open‐label study. The participants were assigned to three groups. Group I was given the Myleop patch as usual for 7 days. Group II was given an aspirin tablet of 75 mg/day. Group III (the trial group) was given both the Myleop patch (POP) and aspirin (AP) (75 mg/day) for 35 days. The end‐points were the incidence of pregnancy, the incidence of bleeding, the duration of bleeding, discontinuation of contraception and adhesive failure. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a phase I study for patients with solid tumor cancer who are undergoing chemotherapy. The study is divided into two parts, namely, Part 1 and Part 2. In Part 1, we will determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) or recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of the combination of TAK-385/TRC105 with chemotherapy. In Part 2, we will evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics (PK), immunogenicity, and anti-tumor activity of the recommended MTD or RP2D in combination with chemotherapy.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a phase I, open-label, multi-center, dose-escalation and expansion study of TAK-385 (JNJ-64293686), TRC105 (Tisagenlecleucel), and chemotherapy in the front-line treatment of patients with previously untreated malignant solid tumors. The primary objective of Part 1 of the study is to determine the MTD or RP2D of the combination by evaluating the toxicities and the maximum tolerated dose for the combination regimen. The secondary objective of this clinical study is to evaluate the pharmacokinetic profiles, immunogenicity, anti-tumor efficacy, and survival rate of TAK-385/TRC105 in combination with chemotherapy. The exploratory objective is to evaluate the long-term efficacy of the combination regimen for the treatment of recurrent/metastatic malignant tumors. The study consists of two parts. Part 1 is the dose-escalation phase and Part 2 is the expansion phase of the study. In Part 1, patients will be treated with TAK-385/TRC105 and chemotherapy until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity occurs. In Part 2, patients will receive the same combination of treatments.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in China. The incidence and mortality of lung cancer are increasing every year. Cisplatin-based comprehensive treatment has been the most widely used method for the treatment of lung cancer, but with the continuous development of immunotherapy in recent years, immune checkpoint inhibitors have emerged as a new anti-tumor therapy, and some clinical studies have demonstrated its efficacy and safety. Based on the above literature, immunotherapy combined with conventional chemotherapy as a frontline treatment is an increasingly important research direction in the field of non-small cell lung cancer. However, for patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer who need comprehensive treatment of lung cancer, chemotherapy-related adverse reactions such as nausea and vomiting are very common, which can bring great pain and suffering to patients. Therefore, this study attempts to use a new 5HT3 receptor antagonist drug, NK-104, to optimize the side effects of chemotherapy-related nausea and vomiting in these patients. The investigator will use NK-104 to pre-treat antiemetic chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting that begins or extends to 30 minutes before chemotherapy, and will also evaluate the efficacy, safety and tolerance of NK-104.

A Multi-center, Phase IIa, Open-label, Parallel-group, Single-dose, Sequentially In-patient Study of NK-104 in Patients With Lung Cancer

Conditions

Nausea and Vomiting by Chemotherapy

* Drug: NK-104

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
There is a need for psychotherapeutic interventions in family caregivers in palliative care due to the mental consequences of the disease trajectory. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBTi) can be considered as a low-cost and time-effective intervention for improving sleep, thus managing insomnia in family caregivers. This study will investigate the effectiveness of two different cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTi) approaches in family caregivers. The study will also examine the impact of CBTi on patient symptoms, the caregiver-patient relationship, and the quality of life of both family caregivers and their care recipients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Family caregiving in patients with advanced cancer is an increasingly important and cost-effective strategy to promote comfort, independence, and quality of life at home. Compared with oncologists, family caregivers have more frequent and continuous nursing interactions and closer relationships with patients. At the same time, cancer diagnosis and progression not only cause physical complications for patients but also bring about mental stress and family conflicts. These stressors, in turn, can lead to caregiver burden, depressive symptoms, and stressful caregiving conditions, affecting the health of family caregivers. Caregiver burden is associated with higher costs, prolonged hospitalization, poor treatment compliance, and increased mortality of cancer patients. As studies involving older adults show that insomnia is prevalent in cancer patients, there is an increasing recognition that sleep problems and their sequelae can impair cognition, worsen pain and fatigue, and lead to poor cancer-related quality of life. Caregivers who provide care for older cancer patients are at a higher risk of insomnia than other caregivers because they have more frequent nursing interactions; high levels of stress are often associated with insomnia symptoms in caregivers. The caregiver-patient relationship is mutually influential for both parties, and both may experience insomnia during caregiver-patient communication. Therefore, it is possible that interventions in family caregivers may improve both the sleep

Abstract:
Objective: To investigate the relationship between cervical cord injury (CCI) and cognitive function and to explore the effect of rehabilitation training on cognitive function in CCI patients. Methods: The experimental group received rehabilitation exercises (including joint passive stretching, functional electrical stimulation, and virtual reality (VR) therapy) after the operation. The control group did not receive rehabilitation training. The mini mental state examination (MMSE) was used to assess cognitive function in the two groups before the operation and after 4 weeks of rehabilitation training. The data were analyzed by SPSS 24.0 software. Results: There was a statistical difference in cognitive function scores between the preoperative and postoperative control group. (P = 0.000). The MMSE scores in CCI patients decreased after the operation, and the decline in cognitive function was statistically significant. There was a significant difference in cognitive function scores between the preoperative and postoperative experimental group. (P = 0.000). The MMSE scores in the CCI patient group increased after 4 weeks of rehabilitation training, and there was a statistical difference. (P = 0.006). Conclusion: The occurrence of CCI can lead to a decrease in cognitive function. Early cognitive intervention can improve cognitive function in patients with CCI.

Abstract:
AIM: To evaluate the therapeutic effect of intravenous (IV) methylprednisolone on refractory oropharyngeal pain following orthognathic (ORTHO) surgery.METHODS: Patients aged > 18 years with refractory oropharyngeal in‐the‐healing pain at 2‐4 weeks after ORTHO surgery were randomly assigned to receive either IV 40 mg methylprednisolone twice daily (morning and evening) (n = 25) for five days (methylprednisolone group) or normal saline as placebo (n = 25) in a randomized, double‐blind manner. The primary end‐points were pain VAS scores and WOMAC pain scores.RESULTS: Significant differences in WOMAC pain scores (P = 0.024) and total WOMAC pain scores (P = 0.032) between the two groups were observed. Pain VAS scores were also significantly different between the two groups 6, 24, and 48 h after first administration (P < 0.05). None of the participants reported severe adverse events throughout the study period.CONCLUSION: The administration of IV methylprednisolone is effective and safe in reducing in‐the‐healing orofacial pain following ORTHO surgery.LEVEL OF EVIDENCE: 1.

Abstract:
Background/Introduction: Intravenous immunoglobin (IVIG) treatment can result in severe headaches, yet few studies focus on the management of headache during IVIG infusion. Objective: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of a preventive treatment strategy using topiramate (TPM) in managing headaches during IVIG infusions. Methods: This double‐blind, randomized, placebo‐controlled study evaluated 31 subjects with a history of headaches during prior IVIG treatments. Subjects were randomized to a treatment group or a control group, which included one 6‐g/kg IVIG treatment. The treatment group received TPM 100 mg orally 3 times per day as a pretreatment for the headache the day prior to infusions until 7 days post‐infusion. The control group received a matching placebo. Headache and migraine were evaluated immediately prior to each infusion and the first 3 days post‐infusion using a visual analog scale. Results: A total of 27 subjects (Treatment Group: N = 14 (7 males, avg. age 38.8 years; Control Group: N = 13 (9 males, avg. age 41.2 years)), completed the study. Headache severity was significantly lower within both groups following baseline IVIG infusion (P < 0.001). No significant difference in headache scores was found among groups during the first day of treatment (P = 0.733). On Day 2 through 7, the treatment group had a significantly lower average headache score when compared to baseline, while the control group reported a significant decrease on Days 1 through 3 of IVIG infusion. Conclusions: Treatment with topiramate prior to an infusion of IVIG in subjects with a history of headache during IVIG infusions may be effective when administered on the day post‐infusion.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Treatment of non-small cell lung cancer NSCLC requires multi-cycle treatment with systemic chemotherapy. The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of the nutrient and anti-cancer drug combination, i.e., cisplatin plus bevacizumab plus apoptosis-inducer resolvin D1 (1-RvD1) or methoxy-resolvin D1 (1-mRvD1) and 10-RvD1, in patients with stage IV NSCLC. A prospective, randomized, multi-center, parallel-group study is performed in order to establish the efficacy and safety of resolvin D1.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Non-Small Cell Lung cancer NSCLC is treated with multi-cycle chemotherapy with cisplatin and bevacizumab. However, the effect of chemotherapy is limited by the development of drug resistance, which leads to tumor progression and drug-related toxicities. Abstract:
Several previous pharmacological investigations have identified a dose‐ and sex‐dependent effect of the opioid peptide substance P on the respiratory system. In order to characterize the neuronal projection of central substance P receptors in the ventral medulla and to investigate the differential role of the 5 N and 5 T subtypes on respiration, we studied substance P microinjection effects into the nucleus tractus solitarii (NTS), an integral part of the cardiorespiratory control network, in three groups of anesthetized rats: (1) sham, (2) 5 N antagonist, (3) 5 T antagonist. Substance P microinjection into NTS abolished the anesthetic/hypoxic ventilatory response in sham group. Respiratory rate, tidal volume, and mean arterial pressure remained unchanged, indicating a generalized CNS inhibition by substance P in sham rats. Substance P injection in the 5 N antagonist group blocked the hypoxic response, while respiratory drive returned in the 5 T antagonist group. In conclusion, we suggest that substance P selectively modulates the respiratory drive through NTS. This effect is mediated by the 5 T substance P receptor subtype.

Abstract:
Background: Previously untreated patients with advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma have a poor prognosis and are usually managed non‐operatively with first line gemcitabine monotherapy or in combination with cisplatin, irinotecan or nab‐paclitaxel. The addition of immunotherapy for this indication has the potential to further improve outcomes. Methods: The study will compare the efficacy and safety of nab‐paclitaxel (70 mg/m<sup>2</sup>), gemcitabine (1000 mg/m<sup>2</sup>) with or without pembrolizumab (200 mg) as first‐line therapy in advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma patients. The primary objective is to evaluate the progression‐free survival (PFS) of the experimental arm, compared with the control arm. Secondary objectives include to evaluate other efficacy endpoints. Safety and tolerability measures will be assessed from treatment‐related adverse events (AEs). Results: The study will enroll up to 100 participants (50 in each arm). An interim futility analysis will be conducted when 50% of the primary endpoint was completed, approximately after 40 participants completed 6 months. Conclusion: The study will fill a research gap by exploring the potential role of immunotherapy in improving the efficacy and safety of gemcitabine‐based chemotherapy in untreated advanced pancreatic cancer patients.

Brief Summary

This is a phase II single-arm, multicenter, open-label, biomarker-driven study of avelumab/Bavencio administered with anti-CD47 antibody in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma. Patients will receive a combination of avelumab and anti-CD47 antibody intravenously (IV). Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a phase II, open-label, multicenter (approximately 16 centers worldwide), single arm study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of avelumab combined with anti-CD47 antibody in patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma. The treatment period is 18 months for the initial phase, and subsequently 36 months (up to 54 months) for the long-term treatment phase in patients with ongoing clinical benefit. The primary endpoints of the study are objective response rate (ORR) per RECIST 1.1 after 12 weeks of treatment, and duration of response. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study aims to assess the use of the ASCEND (Allergy Sensitive Cell Enumeration and Neural Dynamics) platform for monitoring respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) bronchiolitis in infants. The study will evaluate if ASCEND can distinguish between mild and moderate/severe RSV bronchiolitis and can guide treatment decisions among infants hospitalized with RSV bronchiolitis. The study will also assess the impact of RSV infections on airway cell activity and T lymphocytes subsets in hospitalized infants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine if the ASCEND platform can distinguish between mild and moderate/severe RSV bronchiolitis and can guide treatment decisions among infants hospitalized with RSV bronchiolitis. This is a prospective cohort study that will include hospitalized infants with RSV bronchiolitis who are age 1-6 months. The study will enroll 30 participants. All infants will be followed from hospital admission until hospital discharge. Blood and tracheal aspirates will be collected from the participants during their hospitalization. The study team will use the ASCEND platform to analyze airway cells and T lymphocytes subsets from the blood and tracheal aspirates. The study team will also monitor the severity of RSV bronchiolitis using standard clinical parameters.

Official Title

The ASCEND Platform for Monitoring Bronchiolitis Severity in Hospitalized Children

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary purpose of this study is to determine the impact of the addition of an oral low dose estrogen regimen for 3-5 years to a standardized, multifactorial intervention on skeletal strength and bone turnover in older adults, thereby improving bone and muscle function.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Introduction: Low-dose estrogen has been used to improve bone density in osteopenic and osteoporotic women. Recent findings, including work from our laboratory, suggest that the benefits of this medication may extend beyond bone, to improving muscle function. This may be through a variety of mechanisms including effects on estrogen receptors (ERs), particularly the membrane ER (mER), which are expressed in muscle. Recent findings from our laboratory and others have revealed that mER signaling has an important role in the innervation, vascularization and metabolism of muscle, with deficiencies in this pathway leading to muscle wasting in aging as well as in neurodegenerative and neuro-metabolic diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. In this study, we will assess the impact of combination therapy with low-dose estrogen and vitamin D on markers of bone and muscle health in 30-59 year-old peri- and postmenopausal women. Objectives: Primary aim: To determine the effect of the combination of low-doses of estrogen and vitamin D, in combination with a multifactorial exercise and nutrition intervention (as a composite measure), compared to the multifactorial exercise and nutrition intervention, on total muscle strength, muscle mass and physical function in peri- and postmenopausal women. Secondary aims: To measure the effects of the combined estrogen and vitamin D, compared to estrogen alone, or vitamin D alone, on bone density, bone turnover, fat mass, cognitive and sleep

Abstract:
The purpose of this study is to clarify the effects of long‐term physical activity on risk factors and coronary endothelial function in overweight and obese men compared to normal weight men. Forty‐two healthy men between 30 and 60 years voluntarily entered the study. Subjects with the body mass index (BMI) over 24 kg/m(2) (n = 25, overweight/obese group) and those with less than 24 kg/m(2) (n = 17, normal weight group) underwent baseline measurements and were then randomly allocated into groups who exercised 4 h/week on a treadmill or on a stationary bicycle, at 40‐60% of the maximal heart rate 3 times per week for 12 weeks. BMI, waist circumference, muscle strength, arterial stiffness, systolic blood pressure (SBP) and the coronary endothelial function were measured before and after the intervention. In 10 days, the effects of single bouts of heavy intensity exercise (80‐100% of the maximal heart rate) were examined. In overweight/obese group, treadmill or cycling exercise significantly improved the coronary endothelial function, arterial stiffness and SBP only without significant changes in muscle strength and body weight. In normal weight group, exercise improved all the parameters studied, although changes in the coronary endothelial function and arterial stiffness were not significant. Acute exercise at above 80% of the maximal heart rate significantly improved the coronary endothelial function and SBP in both groups. These results suggest that long‐term light to moderate intensity exercise can improve arterial stiffness and SBP of overweight/obese people, and that the coronary endothelial dysfunction may not be reversed even by the improvements in arterial stiffness and SBP.

Abstract:
INTRODUCTION: Gait disorders are a common sign of stroke. Although there are many methods for gait assessment, some assessments focus on the subjective experience of walking, which may be subject to a variety of factors. This study investigated the reliability and validity of the Gait Sub‐Scale of the Functional Ambulance Category (FAC) scale, developed by the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS), and its correlations with clinical evaluation and other gait measurement systems. METHOD: One hundred and seventeen stroke patients were recruited, with no significant difference between patient characteristics. Inter‐rater reliability and test‐retest reliability were evaluated. FAC scale scores were compared with timed two minimum (TM2M), six minimum (SM6M), and ten minimum (TM10M) walking tests, Fugl‐Meyer assessment (FMA), lower limb motor function impairment (LMFI) test, and motor score. RESULTS: FAC scale scores showed good inter‐rater and test‐retest reliability. The FAC scale scores were closely correlated with TM2M (r = 0.844; p < 0.001), r = 0.865; p < 0.001), and r = 0.854; p < 0.001; SM6M (r = 0.715; p < 0.001), FMA (r = 0.806; p < 0.001), r = 0.792; p < 0.001) and LMFI test (r = 0.742; p < 0.001), r = 0.871; p < 0.001), and motor score (r = 0.686; p < 0.001), respectively. The results indicate that the FAC scale is a reliable and valid instrument for assessing gait impairment in stroke

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: Pre‐emptive transfusion (PT) has become established in the care of sickle cell disease (SCD) patients with pain, but little is known regarding the clinical efficacy. This prospective randomized clinical trial aimed to study the effect of Pt on analgesia, emergency‐department (ED) visits, ED stays, ED resource use and hospitalizations. METHODS: Seventy‐four children with acute sickle crisis (ASC) and hemoglobin (Hb) levels below 6 g/dL were randomized to receive either Pt or control arm (no transfusion). The children randomized to transfusion had 3 additional hospital day admissions. RESULTS: Pt group had a decrease in the mean number of vasopressors' hours/day (94.0 ± 235.2 vs. 33.6 ± 283.0 hours/day, p=0.005) but a longer mean duration of hospitalization (13.8 ± 11.3 days vs. 8.1 ± 7.6 days, p=0.017) as compared to control. The difference in time between onset of crisis and study enrollment was greater in the Pt group as compared to the control (63.4 ± 39.0 hours vs. 21.2 ± 13.9 hours, p=0.028). CONCLUSION: This study did not demonstrate a statistically significant advantage for Pt in the treatment of ASC. Pt prolongs the stay but decreases the requirement of inotropes in the management of ASC. Pt should hence be reserved for children presenting in a pre‐terminal deteriorating state and may not be of benefit in mild to moderate ASC.

Exclusion Criteria:

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
An experimental study. The primary objective is to know by experience / observation whether to perform a reverse shoulder prosthesis replacement surgery in patients with rheumatoid arthritis or cuff-tear patients, it gives a 15% improvement in the range of movement if a deltoid release (split deltoid muscle) is performed in combination with a reverse shoulder prosthesis. For this, the movement of the limb to be operated on will be examined and recorded for the same rheumatic disease and operation and 6 and 12 months after the operation. The hypothesis is: that the deltoid section (split) and the reverse shoulder prosthesis replacement surgery allows an increase in the movement of the limb and allows the use of an assistive device less than before surgery (less pain).

Detailed Description
-----------------
We will conduct a prospective, controlled intervention study in parallel groups. Recruitment will include 20 patients with shoulder pain and immobile due to Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) or massive rotator cuff lesions, who will be operated on with a reverse shoulder prosthesis, with the addition of a deltoid section in the group with deltoid section and another 20 patients with the same pathology but with only reverse Shoulder Prosthesis. Patients will be randomized. Clinical data will be taken one month prior to surgery. The outcome measures will be the pain scale (0-10) and movement in the operated shoulder which will be measured just before surgery, 2 months and 6 months after the surgical procedure.

Official Title
-----------------
Deltoid Release for Reverse Shoulder Prosthesis Replacement: Does It Make a Difference?

Conditions
-----------------
Shoulder Pain; Rotator Cuff Rupture

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Procedure

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Ketamine has been shown in numerous studies to provide significant reduction in intraoperative blood loss, analgesia, sedation and anesthesia . There is an inverse relationship between the dose of a drug used and the efficacy of that drug. Anesthesiologists may believe that lower dose of anesthetic or analgesic agents will help reduce the complications that may be associated with high doses. This has been extensively studied in sedation cases, in which administration of a 0.5 mcg/kg dose of Ketamine has shown to reduce intraoperative blood loss and provide analgesia and sedation equivalent to that of propofol. There are no studies that have compared intraoperative blood loss, sedation, pain relief during the intraoperative period, and intraoperative fentanyl requirement between a 0.5 mac/kg dose of Ketamine and 0.5 mg/kg of propofol administered in both the induction and infusion of anesthesia. This study will prospectively compare the combination of 0.5 mg/kg propofol with 0.5 mcg/kg ketamine as a bolus, compared to a propofol induction and infusion of the same rate throughout the operation, for the control. We hypothesize that the combination of 0.5 mg/kg propofol along with 0.5 mcg/kg ketamine has an advantage over propofol alone for intraoperative and postoperative analgesia, sedation, and anesthesia, and also decreases the amount of fentanyl used, and therefore lowers the intraoperative blood loss, without affecting the hemodynamic values.

Official Title
-----------------
Comparison of Propofol Plus Low Dose Ketamine Vs Propofol Alone for Anaesthesia and Pain Relief

Conditions
-----------------
Chronic Pain, General An

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to collect and test the genetic material of patients with acromegalism, to evaluate and analyze the underlying genetic mutations and analyze whether mutations of these genes are associated with clinical manifestations of neuropsychiatric diseases, such as dementia and neurocognitive dysfunction.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The researchers will invite patients with acromegalism in the hospital to participate in this study. At the same time, the patients' clinical data, relevant imaging examination, and blood samples will be retrospectively collected. The researchers will also ask the patients to provide saliva samples. On this basis, whole exome sequencing and targeted sequencing will be conducted on the patients. The researchers will screen the known pathogenic genes and perform targeted gene variation verification and Sanger sequencing. The researchers will also analyze the correlations between variants and patient clinical manifestations, and the correlation of these genes with neurocognitive diseases to explore the pathogenesis of acromegalism and its neurocognitive problems. Finally, the researchers will collect the patients' medical information and genetic sequencing results to establish the researchers' biospecimen library and gene bank for acromegalism.

Official Title
-----------------
To Validate the Association Between the Genes Related to the Development of Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Other NCD's and Acromegaly

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
We planned this study to prove that it is not only appropriate but necessary to perform thrombectomy for patients with acute occlusion of the intracranial vertebrobasilar artery. And, we need to clarify what types of patients will benefit from this treatment by prospectively measuring the severities of ischemic lesions before and after treatment. (1) To assess the efficacy of thrombectomy for thrombosis of the vertebrobasilar artery by the functional outcome, and if there were no effect, to set our goal for the therapy from now on. (2) To assess the severity of brain infarction before and after thrombectomy by diffusion-weighted magnetic resonance imaging (MRI.) In addition, we would like to assess the severity of brain infarction in relation to the severity of neurological abnormalities, such as NIHSS and mRS. To perform this study, clinical data and images are collected and analyzed in a real-world setting. This study is planned as a retrospective study to prove the necessity of thrombectomy for thrombosis of the vertebrobasilar artery.

Detailed Description
-----------------
At the time of admission to our hospital with vertebrobasilar artery thrombosis in patients with poor prognosis in the past, the doctor was reluctant to perform an operation due to concerns about the poor outcome after the operation and complications of the procedure such as brain hemorrhage etc. As a result, there was not enough data to judge whether the surgery was successful or not. However, we found that even large cerebral thrombosis could be treated successfully by thrombectomy, including the operation for acute cerebellar infarction, in recent years. Furthermore, we have the expectation that even the vertebral artery thrombosis can be removed because the vertebral artery is adjacent to the external carotid artery. It is thought that by accumulating clinical data and analyzing it, we will be able to determine whether thrombectomy for the vertebral artery is possible and establish a treatment strategy.

These complications are associated with high mortality rates and increase the ICU burden. In the ICU, the average nursing workload is considered to be between 3–5 care events per hour, and this number is expected to increase due to the growing severity of illness and the increasing need for intravenous therapies. ICU nurses often care for multiple patients, which has led to overcrowding and the use of multitasking, but this has not necessarily improved patient outcomes. In our case study, we observed that central‐line care bundle implementation had a significant effect on patients, and it led to greater safety in the ICU. Despite these findings, central‐line care bundle implementation needs to be more standardized to ensure consistent results. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of central‐line care bundle implementation in the ICU on the quality and safety of care. Methods: The study was a before and after comparative study. In the first place, 100 randomly selected patients who stayed in the ICU for less than 24 hours were enrolled as a control group. In the next stage, 100 more patients were selected, and they received the care bundle intervention. Then, both control and intervention groups were assessed in a before and after study. The primary outcome was the rate of central‐line associated bloodstream infections, and the secondary outcomes included the ICU length of stay, ICU mortality rate, and 30‐day mortality rate. Results: Among the 200 patients included in the study, there was no significant difference in mortality (p = 0.354). The central‐line associated bloodstream infection rate was found to be lower in the intervention

Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients who have a history or presence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and will undergo lobectomy are candidates for this trial. The purpose is to determine oxygen saturation (SPO2) with different concentrations of oxygen during and after the operation.

Detailed Description
-----------------
In this prospective comparative observational cohort study, 51 patients (American Society of Anesthesiologists [ASA] 1-3 and with American Lung Association [ALA] grade of COPD as C or above) scheduled for lung resection are included. Patients are divided into two groups: a control group and a study group. The control group receives supplemental oxygen at 5 L/min; the study group receives supplemental oxygen at a rate determined by the oxygen saturation (SPO2) during and after the operation to maintain SPO2 at 92%, at 88%, lower than 88%, and at 90% during inspiration. The primary outcome is the rate of decline in oxygen saturation (SPO2) during and after the operation. For patients in the control group, the SPO2 decreases as the FIO2 increases; however, in the study group, the SPO2 decreases as the FIO2 increases but not to a significant degree. In this study, we found that compared with supplemental oxygen at a fixed flow rate of 5 L/min, oxygen supplementation at a rate determined by the SPO2 during and after the operation to keep the SPO2 at a certain level during inspiration can maintain a stable SPO2. Compared with supplemental oxygen at a fixed flow rate of 5 L/min, oxygen supplementation at a rate that adapts to the SPO2 during and after the operation to maintain SPO2 at a certain level during inspiration can more effectively maintain adequate oxygenation in patients with COPD.

The purpose of this study is to determine the influence of various preoperative treatments on postoperative depression and anxiety level of patients and to further explore the specific factors affecting the postoperative anxiety and depression level of patients.

It affects about 40% of patients undergoing major or invasive treatment and surgery, and seriously affect the postoperative recovery of patients, increase the physical and mental stress of patients, prolong the recovery time after operation, and even affect the prognosis and quality of life of patients. It has been shown that anxiety and depression in postoperative patients have a strong association with the operation itself, the condition of the patient, the anesthetic drug used and whether the operation is elective or emergent. Various factors such as gender, age, and education level may affect the level of postoperative anxiety and depression. Anesthesia type and its method of administration may also be affecting factors for some operations. But the results are still unclear. The purpose of this study is to determine the influence of various preoperative treatments on postoperative depression and anxiety level of patients and to further explore the specific factors affecting the postoperative anxiety and depression level of patients. We will conduct a prospective cohort study based on prospective randomized controlled trials. Patients who are scheduled to undergo spinal or epidural anesthesia surgery for a variety of surgical procedures will be recruited as subjects. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether preoperative adjunctive nimodipine reduces the incidence of cardiopulmonary and perioperative complications in elderly patients undergoing abdominal aortic surgery. The investigators hypothesized that the use of nimodipine in elderly patients undergoing abdominal aortic surgery will reduce the incidence of cardiopulmonary complications, improve the rate of return to normal bowel function, reduce the number of postoperative complications, and improve quality of life.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Abdominal aortic surgery is a major operation in elderly patients, the incidence of postoperative complications after surgery is very high, and the mortality is as high as 10%. At present, there is no definite preventive treatment for its prevention and treatment. Clinical research has shown that calcium antagonists are widely used in the clinical treatment of cerebral ischemia, hypertensive emergency, and heart failure. Studies have also confirmed that calcium antagonists have an effective effect on reducing cardiovascular risk. Abstract:
Cigarette smoking is still the most widespread risk for heart failure among the risk factors. The mechanisms by which cigarette smoking affects heart failure remain unclear. Therefore, we investigated the correlation between smoking status and serum high‐sensitivity C‐reactive protein levels and NT‐proBNP (pro‐B‐type natriuretic peptide) in patients with a reduced and preserved LV ejection fraction of heart failure. The study was performed retrospectively and included 95 patients with a reduced LVEF and 105 patients with a preserved LVEF of heart failure and 30 healthy subjects as controls. There was a significant positive correlation between serum NT‐proBNP levels and levels of high‐sensitivity C‐reactive protein and smoking status in both patients with a reduced LVEF (r = 0.43 and 0.30) and levels of high‐sensitivity C‐reactive protein and smoking status in patients with a preserved LVEF (r = 0.41 and 0.27). There was a significant positive correlation between levels of NT‐pro BNP and levels of serum high‐sensitivity C‐reactive protein (r = 0.69) in patients with a reduced LVEF and a significant positive correlation between levels of NT‐proBNP and levels of serum high‐sensitivity C‐reactive protein (r = 0.44) in patients with a preserved LVEF. In conclusion, smoking affects the severity of heart failure, even in the subgroup of patients with a preserved LVEF. This finding provides a deeper understanding of the disease burden and may lead to earlier diagnosis and more aggressive therapy.

In-depth interviews of all participants will be conducted using the questionnaire of sexual function and sexual libido. This aims to report any change in their sexual function and libido after varicocele ligation that is performed on them.

Background and Rationale
-----------------
The primary purpose of this study is to provide information whether or not a pharmaceutical product, called CXNTRAX (CXNTRAX is the name of the proposed drug and refers to  IBI302 in medical terminology) works in lung cancer. It is an anti-tumor agent that triggers a person's natural immune system. It works by binding to a group of proteins called CXCR4, which are found on different types of blood cells, including immune cells. The study will test whether the drug can help to reduce the growth and spread of cancer in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), which is one of the leading causes of cancer death worldwide. The study will evaluate both the safety and effectiveness of the drug at various doses, as well as the optimal dose to be used in future studies. The study will be conducted in about 150 patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer who have not responded to standard treatment or have progressed after treatment. The study is divided into three stages: a dose selection phase, an efficacy and safety evaluation phase, and an extension phase. In the dose selection phase, patients will be randomly assigned to receive one of four different doses of CXNTRAX (300 mg, 1000 mg, 2000 mg, or 3000 mg), or a placebo (an inactive substance that looks the same as the actual drug). 
During the efficacy and safety evaluation phase, patients who respond well to treatment or show no signs of disease progression will receive CXNTRAX at the previously determined optimal dose, while patients who do not respond well to treatment or show signs of disease progression will continue to receive their assigned dose of CXNTRAX or placebo until their condition worsens or they experience unacceptable side effects. Abstract:
Melanoma lesions treated with excisional surgery have substantial risk of recurrence. This study was conducted to determine risk factors for local recurrence following surgery. Patients with primary cutaneous melanoma treated with complete excision of the primary lesion were included in a prospective randomized, controlled trial of adjuvant therapy with isotretinoin. After randomization, patients were treated for 8 months with oral isotretinoin. All clinical and laboratory data after surgery, including histopathologic evaluation of the original specimen, were collected and analyzed to identify risk factors for recurrence. During the 6‐month follow‐up, 72 (18%) patients had 73 local recurrences, while 751 (17%) recurred at a later time. The frequency of local recurrence was higher in the lymph node‐negative patients (20%) than in those with lymph node involvement (4%) (P < .001). An ulcerated primary melanoma was a significant risk factor for local recurrence (P < .001). Patients who had a recurrence before the end of follow‐up (< 6 months) had a greater than 2‐fold increase in risk for recurrence at a later time (hazard ratio = 2.3; 95% confidence interval: 1.2‐4.3; P < .001). Patients with local recurrence had a significantly greater tumor thickness (4.8 mm vs 3.8 mm; P = .006) compared with those with no recurrence. Tumor ulceration was a significant risk factor for local recurrence. Patients with local recurrence have a greater than 2‐fold increase in risk for recurrence at a later time.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND: Patients with newly diagnosed localized head and neck cancer in Japan are relatively younger and have fewer comorbidities compared to patients from other countries. This study was conducted to evaluate the 3‐year survival ratio for patients with localized nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal carcinoma who underwent surgery, postoperative radiotherapy, and adjuvant therapy.METHODS: The subjects of the present study were 190 patients with localized nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal carcinoma who underwent surgery, postoperative radiotherapy, and adjuvant therapy from January 2000 to December 2009 at our hospital. The patients were divided into two groups: group A (<60 years of age, 60 patients), and group B (>60 years of age, 130 patients). Survival rates and prognostic factors for 3‐year survival were assessed for both groups.RESULTS: In group A, 31 (51.7%) patients developed distant metastases after initial treatment. The 3‐year survival rate was 83.9%, with a 5‐year survival rate of 75.6%. In group B, 84 (64.6%) patients developed distant metastases after initial treatment. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate whether a self-guided meditation and mindfulness intervention reduces cognitive decline and improves executive functioning. Participants will be randomized into the intervention and control group to determine if self-guided meditation and mindfulness leads to reduced cognitive decline.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A self-guided meditation and mindfulness intervention for adults, consisting of 4 weekly sessions, led by an oncologist oncology social worker and psychologist oncology staff will be evaluated in this research study. The group sessions will take place via zoom or in-person and utilize techniques and technologies such as smartphone apps, handouts, audiovisual media, journaling, and other creative expression tools. The sessions will include meditation and mindfulness techniques, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) for cancer, and psycho-oncology interventions. Researchers will also provide information and tools for participants to continue their meditation and mindfulness practices once the sessions are complete. The research intervention is a 4-week series of weekly sessions that includes: Education about the biopsychosocial aspects of cancer and well-being Sessions that focus on guided imagery and meditation Sessions that use CBT strategies and techniques to reduce anxiety and improve mindfulness Practice suggestions to integrate relaxation mindset into daily activities Researchers will assess participants cognitive-flexibility, self-efficacy, state anxiety, stress, mindfulness, and quality of life at baseline, at the end of the intervention and then again at 6-month follow up to determine the effectiveness of the intervention on these aspects. Participants will be asked to complete phone or zoom interviews to assess their overall satisfaction with the program at the end of the intervention, and they may elect to provide feedback about their participation in the program. Participants will also be asked to complete a short questionnaire at 6-month follow-up to assess any long-term effects of the intervention.

Official Title
-----------------
The Pilot Randomized Open Study of a Multi-Component Intervention to Improve Quality

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
BACKGROUND: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an important cause of cardiovascular disease and stroke. Current guidelines recommend the use of anticoagulants for patients with AF and increased risk of stroke. However, recent studies have suggested that aspirin monotherapy may be a suitable alternative to anticoagulants in patients with stroke risk scores between 0 and 2. A recent study found that in elderly patients with AF and recent history of minor stroke or transient ischemic attack, aspirin monotherapy resulted in a significant reduction in intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) compared to warfarin monotherapy. However, no studies have evaluated the efficacy and safety of aspirin monotherapy in Korean AF patients. In particular, there are limited data available on the use of aspirin monotherapy in combination with antiplatelet agents in these patients. This study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of aspirin monotherapy in Korean AF patients with low stroke risk. STUDY DESIGN: This prospective, open-label, randomized, non-inferiority trial will randomly assign 603 patients with AF aged 75 years or older who were not candidates for oral anticoagulant therapy to the aspirin monotherapy group (n=301) or the aspirin + clopidogrel group (n=302). The primary outcome of the study will be the combined rate of composite outcomes of stroke and systemic embolism (SE) during a 1-year follow-up period. The study will also assess the risk of ICH, major bleeding, cardiovascular mortality, and all-cause mortality in both groups. The results of this study will help determine the optimal therapeutic strategy for stroke prevention in Korean AF patients with low stroke risk.

The objective of this study is to evaluate the effect of 1.2 Gy/minute fractionated stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (FSABR) to the prostate in patients with adverse intermediate to intermediate risk prostate cancer, using 3D conformal radiotherapy (3DCRT) and intensity‐modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) treatment planning techniques and three dimensional magnetic resonance imaging (3D MRI)‐based dose computation dosimetric evaluations. In the planning of FSABR, dose constraints for organs‐at‐risk and rectal dose reduction were imposed. The plan quality and dosimetric outcomes of prostate and rectum for all techniques were compared. For all three techniques, the V95 of the prostate gland was 100% (100%). The V92 of the rectum 4 mm from the prostate‐rectum interface was 39%, 40%, and 39% for 3DCRT, IMRT, and FSABR, respectively. There was no statistically significant difference in mean rectal dose for different treatment plans which ranged from 36 Gy with 3DCRT to 42 Gy with IMRT. The equivalent uniform dose (EUD) parameters were similar between 3DCRT and IMRT. The mean EUD D98 (D98) of prostate ranged from 104.0 (104.0) Gy with 3DCRT to 94.2 Gy (104.7 Gy) with IMRT; the equivalent uniform dose (EUD) parameters were similar between 3DCRT and IMRT. 3DCRT is a feasible technique for delivering 3DCRT in the planning of FSABR ‐ IMRT‐based treatment plans in adverse intermediate to intermediate risk prostate cancer. Dose constraints for V92 were similar for all techniques. Rectal dose reduction was achieved by employing IMRT and FSABR planning algorithms

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
To improve the efficiency of wound healing, a new and more precise imaging technology, microvessel ultrasound imaging, has been developed. This technology is used to track the flow of blood to the wound site, enabling a more detailed understanding of the healing process and the factors that influence it. The main purpose of this study is to compare the healing process of chronic leg ulcers with and without microvessel ultrasound imaging. Chronic leg ulcers are wounds that do not heal, or if they do, they heal very slowly. They are a challenge for healthcare professionals because the rate of recurrence is high. These ulcers affect patients' quality of life. This study compares the wound healing process with microvessel ultrasound imaging compared to the historical control. The main goal is to evaluate whether the use of this new imaging technology significantly improves wound healing. The study will be conducted in two phases: a prospective phase with patients receiving treatment, and a retrospective phase with patients receiving standard treatment. The study will include approximately 220 participants, each with a leg ulcer. In the prospective phase, a group of participants will be randomly selected and will receive treatment with and without microvessel ultrasound imaging. The other group of participants will receive only standard treatment. The microvessel ultrasound imaging will be performed at each visit, and data will be collected on wound healing and other clinical signs. After the end of the prospective phase, the retrospective phase will start. A group of previously treated patients will be selected and will undergo microvessel ultrasound imaging. This group will have previously followed a treatment program, and the results will be compared to those obtained by the prospective group.

-----------------
The study is aimed at the optimization of wound healing in patients affected by chronic leg ulcers. It uses microvessel ultrasound imaging with microbeam technology, with the objective

Abstract:
OBJECTIVE: To evaluate a novel noninvasive microvessel ultrasound technology compared to conventional clinical and dermoscopic criteria in predicting response to split‐thickness skin grafting (STSG).METHODS: This cohort study was conducted in a plastic and reconstructive surgery unit in a single large university hospital. We retrospectively analyzed data on 31 patients who had undergone skin grafting between January 2014 to December 2018. Diagnoses were non‐melanoma skin cancer, trauma, or infection. We performed a blinded analysis on images taken using the Vessel View™ HD microvessel ultrasound scanner. We compared our microvessel ultrasound measurements with conventional clinical criteria such as wound area, ulcer duration, and clinical presentation.RESULTS: On linear regression univariate analysis, increasing capillary area was associated with improved STSG take rate (P = .003), as was increased perfusion area (P = .005). Increased density (mean: 0.45), capillary area (mean: 0.23 cm), and perfusion area (mean: 0.26 cm) had strong positive correlations with clinical diagnosis at the time of graft. However, microvascular ultrasound metrics had poor correlations with clinical diagnosis after STSG. The AUC for ROC curve analysis indicated that microvascular density (0.629) had modest accuracy in predicting grafting outcome. The microvessel technology had significant discriminatory power when correlated with the grafting technique and anatomic location.CONCLUSIONS: Our microvessel imaging technology offers promising accuracy compared to clinical observations in evaluating wound beds and predicting grafting outcomes. Microvascular density showed modest accuracy in predicting grafting outcomes, with improved accuracy when specific patient groups are considered.

Objective To investigate the mechanism of action of high-intensity focused ultrasound (HIFU) during magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) by histology and immunology, and to detect the role of inflammatory factors and extracellular matrix in the therapeutic effect of HIFU on hyperplasia of the prostate. Background The efficacy and short-term safety of magnetic resonance guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) have been proved. To investigate the mechanism of action of MRgFUS on the tissue, more studies should be conducted. The investigators will perform clinical trials, immunofluorescence studies, and quantitative polymerase chain reaction for mRNA expression after MRgFUS therapy, and to compare the level of expression of genes related to inflammatory reaction and extracellular matrix. Methods Sixty patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) were randomly divided into low-intensity group, high-intensity group and control group, and were treated with MRgFUS for prostatic hyperplasia. Patients were followed up for 2 and 4 months after surgery. Erectile function, urinary symptom, quality of life and other related clinical indicators before surgery and prostate, serum and urine samples after surgery were tested.

T-SSEP was obtained using a T-SSEP machine (BioSpectal Instruments, Inc., New York City, USA) to acquire and record signals from the upper limb. The upper limb should be uncovered completely during the whole recording process. Before the start of recording, the patients lay down for 5 min in a quiet and comfortable room and their upper limbs rested in a prone position on the test table. After ensuring that all the recording electrodes have been attached to the relevant electrodes, T-SSEP signals were collected for 60 s followed by 20 s rest. This process was then repeated with the participants moving their upper limbs 10 times in 20 s. After each test, a standardized resting period of 5 min was given. All examinations were performed by the same researcher in order to reduce errors. The data of every two tests were average analyzed as the final data.

Abstract:
Aortic diameter changes in response to 21 years of blood pressure lowering in men with mild to moderate uncomplicated hypertension. Analysis of data from the Hypertension Detection and Follow‐up Program shows that antihypertensive treatment induced regression of aortic size in patients with initial diastolic blood pressures (DBPs) between 95 and 105 mm Hg. A greater magnitude of regression was seen in patients with lower initial DBPs. The mean (± SD) DBP at the beginning of the study was 97.5 ± 5.9 mm Hg; the mean (± SD) yearly DBP changes before treatment were 5.0 ± 14.8 mm Hg. Regression did not develop after 5 years of treatment and was only observed in patients with lower initial DBPs. This study shows that aortic size is lower after 21 years of antihypertensive treatment in men with mild to moderate uncomplicated hypertension who present no evidence of clinical atherosclerosis. The data indicate that there is an inverse relationship between DBP at the time of drug initiation and magnitude of aortic regression and that the magnitude of aortic regression over 5 years of follow‐up can be reduced by increasing the initial DBP levels.

Methods: An observational, hospital records review study was conducted on primary angle‐closure glaucoma patients treated with low‐dose MPD from January 2014 to December 2017 at one institute hospital department. The aim of the study was to evaluate the effect of short‐term MPD in lowering IOP, preventing visual field loss, and preventing attacks during the preoperative period. Primary angle‐closure glaucoma is generally treated by minimizing intraocular pressure (IOP). Steroid preoperative treatment is a common therapeutic option for IOP control. However, the standard MAP‐600 method of steroid treatment has a risk and contraindication to the patient's health. As a result, a low‐dose MPD was chosen as a substitute for the standard MAP‐600 method. A retrospective investigation of the safety and efficacy of low‐dose MPD in patients with severe primary angle‐closure glaucoma. Abstract:
Animal handling studies are important in the development of drugs and in the application of animal models to study complex diseases in animals. However, animal handlers are often unaware of the welfare of the animals, creating a lack of empathy and attachment and resulting in less humane treatment. A solution to this problem is the application of human‐animal interaction training with animals. Interaction training is a process of learning and socialization for novice handlers and has been applied worldwide to help them understand the needs, communication, and behavior of animals. An example of such a program can be found in the European Union. It was developed to encourage handlers to think of animal welfare by providing educational modules on the biology and behavior of lab animals in addition to training to create a relationship with them. This interactive training program enables handlers to observe the animals' behavior to assess whether it is consistent, develop positive interactions with the animals, and develop a better attitude towards animal welfare. The training modules included in the program are based on the principles of social and cognitive learning. The modules address topics such as animal housing, diet and supplements, environmental enrichment, handling, and restraint. They are structured in a step‐by‐step manner starting with the understanding and definition of animal ethics, continuing with communication strategies with animals, and including tips on the appropriate handling of laboratory animals. The content of the training modules is adapted to the species‐specific needs and requirements of the animals, which helps to build a foundation for a positive relationship between the handler and the animals. The training program also emphasizes the importance of providing species‐specific enrichment to enhance animal welfare and well‐being. Animal handlers should be provided with a positive work environment, be motivated, and receive regular supervision to ensure the success of the program. The effectiveness of the training program is evaluated by monitoring the behavior and health of the animals, the attitude of the handlers towards animal welfare, and the feedback from animal welfare officers. This training program has been found to be effective in reducing animal stress, improving animal welfare, and enhancing the performance of animal

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to evaluate the impact of perioperative nutrition support and exercise on physical function in elderly frail women undergoing radical gastrectomy for total gastrectomy for gastric cancer.

Detailed Description
-----------------
At the moment, there is little literature on the recovery of physical function and body composition in elderly frail women undergoing radical gastrectomy for gastric cancer. In addition, there is a lack of study of the interaction between protein, energy, exercise, and physical function in elderly frail women. The primary purpose of the study is to evaluate the impact of nutrition support (protein and energy) and exercise on physical function in elderly frail women undergoing radical gastrectomy for total gastrectomy for gastric cancer. The primary study hypothesis is that nutrition support (protein and energy) and exercise will increase the levels of ghrelin, leptin, GH/IGF-1, and testosterone and improve body composition. The secondary study hypothesis is that the implementation of protein and energy nutrition support with exercise will reduce levels of IL-6, C-reactive protein, and oxidative stress, which are important indicators of frailty, promote immune function and quality of life in elderly frail women, and improve their physical function.

Official Title

Evaluation of the Effect of Exercise and Nutrition Support (Protein and Energy) on Improving Body Composition and Physical Function in Elderly Frail Women Undergoing Gastric Surgery for Total Gastrectomy for Gastric Cancer

Brief Summary

This study assesses the influence of the patient's peri-implant condition on the outcome of two different digital workflows for restoring missing teeth with implant supported mandibular overdentures.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The main objective of this study is to assess the implant survival, marginal bone level (MBL) maintenance, patient satisfaction and denture stability in comparison between two distinct digital workflow solutions in patients with moderate and advanced peri-implant mucositis. The following digital workflow solutions will be compared: Conventional impression → Computer Aided Design/ Computer Aided Manufacturing (CAD/CAM) versus Digitally scanned impression → CAD/CAM; In 10 patients with mild to moderate Peri-implant Mucositis (PIM), implant supported mandibular overdentures will be fabricated using the conventional impression workflow in combination with a CAD/CAM restoration. The same 10 patients will furthermore undergo digitization of the dento-gingival arch to evaluate a workflow in which intraoral scans are used to generate a digital model from which only the overdenture base will be CAD/CAM-fabricated; In 10 patients with moderate to advanced PIM, dento-gingival scans will be used to evaluate the outcomes of a fully digital impression and manufacturing workflow. This will be the same as in the first 10 patients but only the overdenture base construction will be CAD/CAM-based. Two different implant abutments will be investigated, the customized abutment (C-AB) and the screw-retained abutment (S-RA), that will be CAD/CAM-fabricated in advance. The implant-supported overdentures will then be delivered. Follow-up examinations will take place after 1, 3 and 6 months to record patient satisfaction and dental stability. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of a diet rich in vitamin C, vitamin A and zinc in young children.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Although there is limited clinical trials assessing the effects of micronutrients on child growth and development, several studies have demonstrated the important and vital role of vitamin A and vitamin C on growth and development in infants, children and adolescents. Micronutrient deficiencies remain prevalent among children in developing countries and the effect of micronutrient on children has been increasingly recognized. In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in the effect of multiple micronutrients on linear growth, anthropometric measurements and neuropsychological development, especially among young children in developing countries. The investigators have already performed a small cross-over study showing the effect of taking zinc and Vitamin A on the growth of children. This study aims to investigate the growth effect of a comprehensive vitamin and mineral supplement on the growth of children in developing countries. The investigators hypothesis is that the daily supplementation of children aged between 18 months and two years of age with a special combination of vitamins and micronutrients improves the growth of the entire group.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this prospective single-centre study is to demonstrate the feasibility of a new type of implant-supported mandibular overdenture that can support a bar-retained mandibular overdenture. The study will compare this new type of implant to the currently available overdenture. The new type of implant has a conical connection between the implant and the overdenture bar, which is hypothesized to have better fixation and greater retention of the overdenture. The feasibility of this new implant design will be evaluated by comparing the bone height, the bone width, and stability, of the previously inserted dental implants with the newly inserted dental implants.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The present randomized cross-over study will compare the new type of dental implant to the currently used overdenture. To this end, a computer-generated randomization table will be used to assign the 64 patients to Group 1 and Group 2. The new type of dental implant will be implanted in the mandible of group 1 (test group) and dental implants according to the protocol of the conventional mandibular overdenture will be implanted into the edentulous mandible of Group 2. After implant insertion, the same overdenture will be constructed. In both groups (test and control) overdenture is provided with a standard metal bar and plastic abutment, which is covered with denture resin, and overdenture retention is achieved with five palatal metal clips. The difference between the two groups is that the overdenture is supported by 4 standard dental implants in the conventional group and by the new type of implant in test group (conical implants with a 3.5 mm x 6.0 mm diameter and a 7 mm length as well as conical connection between the implant and the implant bar) (Figures 1-2).
