Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether rhPSMA-7.3 (18F) positron emission tomography/computed tomography (PET/CT) can improve the accuracy of conventional imaging and changes in medical management decisions for men with high-risk prostate cancer. Prostate cancer is a common cancer in men and commonly manifests with elevation in prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level. A large percentage of these patients present with high nuclear grade histology (i.e., Gleason score ≥ 7) and/or clinically detectable disease as measured by standard-of-care imaging such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Unfortunately, standard-of-care imaging commonly misses sites of occult disease and is not always able to identify which patients have low, intermediate or high-risk disease. For example, in biochemical recurrence after definitive therapy (radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or radiotherapy) for prostate cancer, approximately 30-60% of patients will experience biochemical recurrence on standard-of-care imaging. However, after treatment, over 90% of men will continue to have a rising PSA and most will go on to have progression of their cancer and metastases. Abstract:
Introduction: There is a growing body of evidence supporting the beneficial effects of low carbohydrate high saturated fat (LCHF) diet on cardiovascular risk. The current study aimed to understand the effects of a LCHF diet on cardiovascular risk factors in obese patients with dyslipidemia. Methods: Twenty four obese individuals aged between 30 and 50 years with dyslipidemia were randomly placed in the intervention group that followed a LCHF diet (13 males, 11 females) and the control group (11 males, 13 females). Both groups followed the same energy and physical activity regimen while the intervention group followed a LCHF diet (carbohydrate and protein 15‐20 and 15‐20%, respectively, of calories) in addition to the energy and physical activity regimen. The energy restriction regimen was conducted for 8 weeks. Results: The LCHF diet led to a significant decrease in body mass index (BMI) and weight (8% reduction, P<0.001) with a significant increase in body lean mass and a slight increase in bone mineral density (P<0.001). Abstract:
Background: Chronic musculoskeletal conditions (CMCs) impose a substantial burden on patients, the healthcare system, and society. As such, prevention is a high priority. The aim of this article is to review exercise prescription and effects on physical activity in CMCs. Methods: Medline, Ebsco, and Web of Science were systematically searched. We included reviews or original studies of musculoskeletal conditions using exercise prescription and exercise referral, providing additional details on type of exercise, effects on physical activity, and intervention characteristics. Results: Seventeen articles fulfilled the inclusion criteria. The most common conditions reviewed were osteoarthritis, heart disease, back pain, and obesity. Moderate‐intensity exercises of combined muscle‐strengthening/aerobic activity were included in the exercise prescriptions. However, effects on physical activity were inconsistent. Conclusions: Additional research is needed to elucidate the effects of exercise prescription on physical activity with a focus on optimal dose, exercise type, and adherence.

Brief summary
=================
Introduction: Low back pain is one of the most Common chronic diseases in the world with high economic and social burdens. Surgical treatment, as indicated, can provide excellent outcomes for managing chronic low back pain. However, the current guidelines provide no evidence for determining whether preoperative or postoperative functional training intervention is a cost-effective treatment for chronic low back pain patients. Methodology: This protocol of this randomized controlled trial was developed by referring to the SPIRIT guidelines. We intend to conduct a prospective randomized controlled study with 100 chronic low back pain patients treated by spine surgery. Participants will be randomly divided into two groups: the intervention group and the control group. Both groups will receive a 12-week rehabilitation program. Additionally, the study will explore the relationship between changes in the function of the cervical and lumbar spine and changes in outcomes after rehabilitation. Conclusion: This randomized controlled trial will be the first prospective study to investigate the effect of a preoperative and/or postoperative rehabilitation program on chronic low back pain patients treated by surgery. The study will hopefully provide a clinical reference for the use of rehabilitation in controlling low back pain.

Abstract:
Cooled radiofrequency (CRF) ablation is a minimally invasive thermal ablation technique used for the treatment of liver cancer. Contrast‐enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) is used to evaluate the ablation margins, however, it is time‐consuming and costly. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is being increasingly used to monitor the CRF ablation process but may not be routinely available. The purpose of this study was to investigate whether diffusion‐weighted imaging (DWI) could be a possible alternative method. DWI and contrast enhanced imaging (CEI) were used for the analysis of treatment effects and treatment completion in 60 patients with hepatocellular carcinoma who received 106‐146 degree Celsius CRF ablation. Liver MRI sequences performed at pre‐treatment, 1‐month, 3‐month, and 6‐month follow‐ups were evaluated for the presence of lesions, perfusion and metabolism within 10‐mm‐radius ROIs using DWI and CEI. DWI showed significant changes in the apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) of ablation regions with treatment duration (P<0.001). CEI showed significant changes in the number of ablated tumors (P<0.001), perfusion parameters (P<0.001), tumor diffusion restriction (P<0.05), and metabolism (P<0.01) of ablation regions with treatment duration. There was no significant difference in the effectiveness of CEI and DWI in the treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma. When compared to CEI, DWI was an easier method to quantify the treatment effect. Our study suggests that both CEI and DWI are valuable tools for CRF ablation tumors, and DWI can be used as an easy‐to‐use alternative to evaluate tumor ablations.

Background: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) accounts for approximately 25% of all breast neoplasms, and it is a heterogeneous disease. Atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH) and low‐medium grade DCIS are not invasive. ADH could be regarded as a precursor of DCIS and has a higher risk of progression to invasive breast cancer. The appropriate management of ADH in the breast is still unclear. According to current research, most ADH is usually followed up with clinical breast examinations and mammography for 2 years. However, recent research suggests that vacuum‐assisted excisional breast biopsy may be a more suitable interventional treatment for ADH to prevent the progression of DCIS. Recently, we conducted a study to assess the efficacy of vacuum‐assisted excisional breast biopsy in patients with ADH. Objective: this retrospective study aimed to investigate the diagnostic precision, therapeutic efficacy, and prognosis of vacuum‐assisted excisional breast biopsy in the treatment of ADH patients. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is an observational, cross-sectional prevalence study on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) among patients with chronic hepatitis B (CHB) infection. As the main route for HBV transmission is horizontal spread, patients with HCC are not required to have anti-hepatitis B core antibodies (anti-HBc). All eligible patients will be invited to participate in the study, and the sample size is approximately 600 cases.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is an observational, cross-sectional prevalence study on HCC among patients with CHB infection. The study will be conducted in the hospital of the Fourth People's Hospital of Jiamusi City, and the patients with CHB infection aged 18-75 years will be enrolled. Abstract:
OBJECTIVES: We aim to determine the incidence of respiratory infection (RI) occurrence in patients receiving autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Secondly, we aim to study the effect of prophylactic strategies on RI occurrence.METHODS: In this retrospective, multicenter study, we reviewed all patients with hematological malignancy who received HSCT at a university hospital between 2012 and 2021 to determine the incidence of RI in the first 6 months post‐HSCT. We used univariate and multivariable analyses to identify factors associated with RI occurrence.RESULTS: A total of 303 patients with hematological malignancy, who received HSCT, were included in the study. Ninety patients (30.0%) were diagnosed with RI in the first 6 months post‐HSCT. Univariate analysis found that the use of the prophylactic agents imatinib, acyclovir, and valgancyclovir, as well as the acquisition of neutrophil engraftment later, were associated with RIF occurrence. The multivariate analysis confirmed these results.CONCLUSION: We found that a relatively high incidence of RIF occurs after HSCT. This study shows that the prophylactic use of imatinib, acyclovir, or valgancyclovir may increase the risk of respiratory infections after HSCT. It suggests that further studies are warranted to determine the effects of prophylactic treatment on RIF occurrence after HSCT.

BACKGROUND: This was the first prospective study to assess the effect of postprandial supplementation with glucagon‐like peptide‐1 (GLP‐1) analogues on insulin secretion in overweight patients with prediabetes. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We conducted a parallel, randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, 4‐week trial with a meal tolerance test 1 day before the last day of the study (with a washout period of 14 days). We enrolled 12 patients with prediabetes (eight men and four women; mean age: 42.9±12.7 years) without known diabetes or a family history of diabetes. Patients were randomly assigned to receive a GLP‐1 receptor agonist (exenatide) or placebo. RESULTS: Exenatide increased the beta‐cell response to the mixed meal (area under the curve of insulin 750‐270minutes: 211.2±100.2 vs. 152.4±73.1mU/L/min, after exenatide and placebo, respectively; P=0.025) and maintained a low glucagon response (P=0.025). As a result of increased insulin secretion without increased insulin resistance (homeostasis model assessment) (P=NS), exenatide attenuated the postprandial glucose response (area under the curve of blood glucose 160‐840minutes: 543.4±527.3 vs. 753.9±809.6mg/dL/min, after exenatide and placebo, respectively; P=0.012). Abstract:
Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI) due to cystic fibrosis (CF) or pancreatic surgery may be associated with chronic malnutrition. In this 4‐week, multicenter, randomized, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled, parallel‐group study, we evaluated the effect of a probiotic formulation on the nutritional status of CF patients with chronic malabsorption. Fifty‐eight children (≥5 years) with CF‐related chronic diarrhea and a body mass index (BMI) z score below ‐1 were randomized to 2 g/day of a synbiotic (BIOGAURD(®)) or placebo, in addition to their habitual diet. Nutritional parameters (caloric intake, daily defecation frequency, nutrient intake, clinical symptoms) as well as body weight, height and BMI z score were determined before and after the study period. At baseline, the subjects had a daily defecation frequency of 10.2 ± 5.2 stools and consumed a mean of 560 ± 130 kcal per day, with inadequate intake of most macronutrients. Mean energy intake increased from 557 ± 155 kcal/day at Week 0 to 915 ± 272 kcal/day at Week 4 (p < 0.01) in the probiotic group and remained unchanged in the placebo group (575 ± 339 to 587 ± 323 kcal/day; p = 0.94). The BMI z score remained unchanged (−0.8 ± 0.9) in the placebo group, whereas it increased by 0.5 in the probiotic group ( p < 0.05). The patients experienced less diarrhea and intestinal pain. Brief Summary

Meningococcal meningitis and meningococcal septicaemia have a high morbidity and mortality rate, despite effective treatment of meningococcal meningitis with a third generation cephalosporin and other supportive therapies . The treatment of meningococcal septicaemia is less well defined. The decision to treat septicaemic patients with cephalosporins with or without penicillin is based on historical data and the local incidence of meningococcal infection. Many patients receive treatment with cephalosporins with penicillin to cover a possible bacteraemia with either Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae, which are also common in neonates. No clinical trials have evaluated the efficacy of this treatment. This prospective, double-blind, double-dummy, randomised, open-labelled, active-controlled trial will evaluate the efficacy and safety of intravenous penicillin in addition to cephalosporin for the treatment of meningococcal septicaemia in neonates. Neonates born in or referred to participating centres from birth to 28 days of age, and who satisfy the inclusion criteria will be eligible for the study. After informed consent has been obtained from parents/guardians, randomisation will be determined using a computer-generated, permuted-block, allocation sequence. Patients with the disease being treated in participating units will be randomised to one of two groups. Purpose: To identify whether pre‐existing cardiac dysfunction can be detected by noninvasive ultrasound and electrical measurements in asymptomatic type 1 diabetes and to follow functional changes during the development of diabetic autonomic neuropathy (DAN). Methods: Patients at the time of type 1 diabetes diagnosis (n = 8) and 1‐3 years post‐diabetes diagnosis (DAN stages 0‐III, 84 patients) were studied. In addition to established methods of autonomic function testing, the sensitivity and specificity of noninvasive, objective cardiac biotensors to detect early cardiac dysfunction were assessed. Diabetic heart involvement was compared to age‐matched, healthy controls (HC, n = 23), and to patients with end‐stage renal disease on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis (ESRD, n = 23). Two‐dimensional echocardiography and 12‐lead electrocardiograms (ECGs) were performed at rest and during handgrip ischemia. Results: In contrast to age‐matched controls, baseline electrocardiograms exhibited prolonged PR intervals (PRI) in type 1 diabetic patients compared to 66 ± 14 msec in control individuals and 71 ± 18 msec in patients with ESRD (p < 0.001), respectively. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a 2-part, open-label, exploratory, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics (PK), and pharmacodynamics (PD) of EKB-001 (carbamazepine 100 mg oral microemulsion) in adults with epilepsy experiencing a partial-onset seizure with or without secondary generalization. Part 1 of the study is to assess the safety and tolerability of multiple 100 mg oral doses of EKB-001 over a 14-day dosing period. In part 2 of the study, 15 mg/kg of levetiracetam (LTG) and 100 mg/day EKB-001 will be co-dosed and compared for a 14-day dosing period. If the study reaches the stopping boundary for futility, then a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled trial will not be conducted. As part 2 is not a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial (DBPCT), it is not an FDA required clinical trial and is not required to be registered.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a 2-part, open-label, exploratory, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, PK, and PD of multiple 100 mg oral doses of EKB-001 and 15 mg/kg LTG over a 14-day dosing period in adults with focal-onset seizures. Part one of the study will assess the safety and tolerability of multiple 100 mg oral doses of EKB-001 over a 14-day dosing period. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a disease involving chronic inflammation that affects the ability to breathe properly. COPD is characterized by expiratory flow limitation that is not fully reversible. Currently, the use of inhaled LAMA as the sole controller in patients with COPD is controversial and evidence is contradictory. Our initial pilot study in patients with COPD found that inhaled LAMA use without inhaled corticosteroids was associated with better lung function and fewer COPD exacerbations. However, whether LAMA alone without inhaled corticosteroids improves the overall prognosis is unclear. The primary aim of this study is to compare the efficacy and safety of LAMA use as the sole controller in patients with moderate-to-severe COPD without a significant history of corticosteroid treatment.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to determine whether inhaled LAMA use results in improved lung function and reduced exacerbation frequency and disease severity in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), without the use of inhaled corticosteroids as a controller medication. The primary endpoint is the change in post-bronchodilator forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) following LAMA administration. The secondary endpoints are the change in exacerbations (any and moderate or severe), the change in post-bronchodilator forced vital capacity (FVC), and the change in disease severity.

Official Title

Assessment of Long-Acting Muscarinic Antagonist Therapy Alone on the Outcomes of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Patients

Abstract:
Purpose: Inhaled anesthesia (IA) for the management of postoperative pain during ambulatory surgery remains challenging due to uncontrolled breathing. Breath control using a mouthpiece can reduce patients' ventilation and thus is suitable for IA. Our aim was to observe ventilation under IA in patients who wore a mouthpiece or a conventional face mask during ambulatory surgery. Methods: One hundred and seventy‐six patients aged between 20 and 55, who were expected to undergo general anesthesia‐based anesthesia, were registered and divided into the mouthpiece group (A) using an orodisc and the face mask group (B) using a face mask. In both groups the patients underwent anesthesia and surgery following the same protocol, and blood gases were observed. Postoperative nausea and headache were also evaluated on the morning following surgery. Results: Compared with the face mask group, the mouthpiece group showed slightly lower pH, lower pCO2, and higher bicarbonate. There was no significant difference in PaCO2 between the two groups. Postoperative nausea occurred in one patient and one patient had slight headache. Conclusion: The mouthpiece is more effective than the face mask for ensuring inhaled anesthetic gas is absorbed during anesthesia, with only minimal differences in PaCO2.

Inclusion Criteria: [IC3] Resident in Canada [IC4] Age 18 or older [IC5] Exclusion Criteria: [EC3] Resident outside of Canada [EC4] Age younger than 18 [EC5] Participation in other cognitive training interventions that address the cognitive abilities of processing speed and working memory in the last 6 months [EC6] Physical, social, and financial barriers affecting engagement in online cognitive training

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive training on memory and executive functions.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness of cognitive training on memory and executive functions. The study will use cognitive training exercises that target processing speed and working memory, both important cognitive abilities in the cognitive reserve theory that supports the ability to compensate for damage to the brain. The study will involve a baseline assessment, randomization into a control group or an intervention group, and follow-up assessments at weeks 4, 8, and 12. The control group will receive no intervention, while the intervention group will participate in cognitive training exercises for 12 weeks. The participants will be asked to complete a series of cognitive tests at each assessment timepoint, which will evaluate their memory, executive functions, and processing speed. The cognitive training program will be delivered entirely online, making it an accessible and attractive option for young adults, in contrast to the limited availability of other methods, such as cognitive rehabilitation sessions conducted in a clinic. The investigators predict that the intervention group will show significant improvements in their cognitive abilities, particularly in terms of working memory and processing speed, compared to the control group. Improvements in cognitive abilities may be especially pronounced among students who lack sleep due to their busy schedules, as better sleep can enhance memory and attention. However, it is important to note that there is a lack of data on the effectiveness of cognitive training in students. The investigators plan to use a two-sample t-test to evaluate the treatment effect and a linear mixed model to examine changes in cognitive abilities over time. The study is expected to make scientific and clinical contributions to the field of cognitive reserve and online cognition training research.

Official Title
-----------------
Cognitive Reserve in Online Cognitive Training Interventions for Young Adults

-----------------
Neurops

Abstract:
Purpose: Palliative care services are increasingly recognized to play an important role in the care of individuals with acute and chronic conditions, such as cancer. However, the effects of palliative programs on functional outcomes are unclear. We evaluated the effect of palliative care referrals on functional status for older individuals with chronic disease and cancer. Method: Adults with chronic disease or cancer on multidisciplinary clinic lists at three academic centres were randomly assigned to receive either a standard of care or a coordinated palliative care program focusing on quality of life. Change in function was assessed using the Geriatric Dependent Function Index (G‐DF) score, a valid and reliable functional outcome score. The trial will allow for assessment of baseline function and changes in function 6 and 12 months post randomization. The primary analysis will compare GDF scores of the two groups over time. A per‐protocol analysis will allow for an assessment of the effects of the intervention on a variety of important outcomes. The final study analysis will be conducted when data collection is complete. AIM: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the pharmacokinetics (PK), efficacy, and safety of cidofovir (CDV) in renal transplant recipients with cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.METHODS: CMV retinitis occurred in 263 of 2,927 recipients with a renal transplant between 1991 and 1996. Patients with retinal detachment or other serious ophthalmic complications, previous treatment with ganciclovir or foscarnet, and patients with CMV retinitis requiring treatment with both intravenous and oral CDV were excluded from analysis. Each patient in this non‐randomized study was assigned an oral CDV dose based on the measured creatinine clearance (CrCl) or the body surface area (BSA). The initial oral CDV dose was 100 mg twice daily (bid) until blood levels of ganciclovir and acyclovir reached steady state (4 days) and then either 100 or 200 mg bid. The first 15 patients received a dose of 200 mg bid. The last 15 patients received a dose adjusted to be 0.5 times the creatinine clearance (CrCl). The CDV serum concentration at steady state was measured by a fluorescence polarizing immunoassay (FPIA). The pharmacokinetic (PK) parameters were measured in 33 patients.RESULTS: The mean oral CDV serum concentration at steady state was approximately 10‐fold lower than that reported previously for intravenously administered CDV. The mean clearances (Cl) corrected for a 1.73 m2 body surface area (BSA) were 48.8 +/‐ 44.9 L/h (ranging from 12.1 to 128.4 L/h) in patients receiving a 100 mg bid dose

Study related to the above title
=================
Severe asthma in primary care: the CAPTURE study.

Is there a rationale for the study?
=================
The purpose of this study is to examine the factors that lead to a severe asthma exacerbation in patients with severe asthma. Patients with severe asthma will be offered 1:1 matched individual patient data (IPD) based on the electronic health record (EHR) of all available GP practices. The CAPTURE study will look at a) the impact of non-adherence to treatment and asthma control, b) asthma health care utilisation in the year period before a severe exacerbation, c) the impact of treatment decisions, d) hospitalisation. A multicentre randomised controlled trial (RCT) with 2 parallel control groups (CG) in primary care is being planned to answer how intensive monitoring (through GP electronic health record data and patient-recorded outcomes) leads to a reduction in severe asthma exacerbations in the next 3 years.

What has the study found so far?
=================
The CAPTURE study database has identified 4500 children with severe asthma with one or more severe asthma exacerbation in the last year and who fulfil the criteria for inclusion in the RCT (to be confirmed). The CAPTURE study has found that (1) the majority (61%) of the children fulfil the criteria for an asthma diagnosis according to the NICE guidelines; (2) most (64%) of the children visit the GP with asthma symptoms four or more days per month; (3) less than one third (32%) have a written asthma action plan. A total of 480 severe asthma exacerbations were recorded in the database but only 148 were hospitalised. In 290 cases asthma was not listed as the reason for the admission. The most common reasons for admission were other (non-asthma) respiratory diseases and asthma and other.

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsGastro-oesophageal cancer (GAC) is the sixth most common cancer in the world and is the fourth leading cause of cancer death. Up to 50% of patients with GAC have advanced or metastatic disease at diagnosis, for which we lack effective treatment. Combining chemotherapy with other drugs is the standard first-line treatment for advanced GAC. However, current regimens are relatively ineffective and carry a high risk of harmful side effects. Therefore, improved treatment is urgently needed. We aim to find a way to improve the response rate and overall survival rate in patients with advanced or metastatic GAC using a combination of chemotherapy plus a drug that has been effective in the treatment of other types of cancers, such as myeloma. In this study, we will compare the effects of oxaliplatin-fluorouracil (L/FOLFOX-4) plus lenalidomide with oxaliplatin-fluorouracil-bevacizumab (B/FOLFOX-4) as first-line treatment for patients with advanced or metastatic GAC who have not been given chemotherapy

Abstract:
Background: This study aimed to evaluate a novel multimodal, early intervention model of care for patients with non‐obstructive acute lower urinary tract symptoms and lower urinary tract symptoms/benign prostatic hyperplasia in primary care with high symptom load. Methods/Principal Findings: The study was a two‐armed parallel‐group randomised controlled trial. The intervention group received an educational booklet regarding the pathology of Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms and access to on‐demand, self‐care advice. The control group received usual care. 871 patients participated in the study. The intervention led to a large treatment effect for both Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms and patient satisfaction. This effect size was larger than for most other interventions for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms. Conclusion: The results suggest that a cost‐effective model combining advice on how to live effectively with Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms and access to on‐demand professional self‐care advice can be an effective and low‐cost way to combat Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Gastric resection syndrome (GRS) is a frequent complication of gastric cancer surgery and results in a decrease in quality of life and functional capacity of patients. This syndrome is characterized by epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, early satiety, heartburn, anorexia, and weight loss. It is attributed to the removal of the upper stomach, which plays a role in providing both motility and gastric-related hormonal responses for digestion in the stomach. Many gastroenterological researchers are investigating this syndrome, but there is no standardized treatment for it. Enteral nutrition (EN) has been shown to be effective in alleviating the symptoms of GRS and maintaining the nutritional status of patients after surgery. However, intravenous infusion of EN (i.v. EN) has been less studied in terms of its benefits in treating GRS. The main objective of this project is to investigate the effects of i.v. EN in patients with GRS, and our hypothesis is that it may alleviate the symptoms associated with GRS, improve nutritional status, and enhance quality of life after surgery.The secondary objectives are to compare the tolerability and satisfaction of i.v. EN with oral EN in patients with GRS and to assess its impact on postoperative symptoms, nutritional status, weight loss, and quality of life. The results of the study will provide important information on the effect of i.v. EN in patients with GRS, and the findings may lead to a new standard of care for these patients.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background and rationale: Gastrectomy is associated with significant changes in gastric acid and pepsin secretion, which can lead to gastric dysfunction, delayed gastric emptying, and nutritional deficiencies. These effects are exacerbated in patients with gastric cancer, leading to the development of gastric resection syndrome (GRS). Abstract:
Background: The objective of this interventional comparative effectiveness (CE) study is to compare two alternative strategies for the management of acute ankle sprains in the community. Methodology/Design: This randomised controlled trial (RCT) evaluates a strategy of 5–10 days of immobilization with aircast for management of acute ankle sprains (ACAS) for a period of 8 weeks, up to 6 months post injury. Patients presenting to general practice (GP) as ambulatory patients with ankle sprain (ACAS, with pain ≥4/10 on the visual analog scale (VAS)) will be recruited. On entry into the trial, patients will be divided into two groups. There are two primary outcomes: proportion of patients without complications 1 month (ACRONIMS, Achilles tendinopathy, osteoarthritis, etc.) and the EuroQol (EQ‐5D) score. The study is designed as an RCT. There are two primary endpoints: the number of participants with complications and the EQ‐5D‐3L score at 1 month. The study will also assess pain intensity, functional disability, health‐related quality of life and patients’ preferences. Discussion: A total of 576 patients are expected to be enrolled in the study, starting in September 2013. With this sample size, we will have 80% power and a two‐sided α<0.025, to detect a clinically relevant difference of 10% for the main primary endpoints. The study will be conducted at 52 primary care centres in Catalonia. Implications: The results of this CE trial may lead to improving the management of ACAS, thus improving the quality of care in the community. They will be used to reduce the use of unnecessary radiography, inappropriate or cost‐intensive treatments in patients with simple spr

Thank you for your cooperation in defining the inclusion criteria for this research. Now, let's focus on the exercise protocols that participants will follow in this clinical research trial. 

The exercise protocols will involve a combination of resistance training and aerobic exercise using different levels of Blood Flow Restriction (BFR). As mentioned earlier, BFR involves placing a tourniquet around the upper arm during exercise, restricting blood flow to the muscles while allowing a partial flow of oxygenated blood. This method has been proposed to help stimulate muscle growth and strength adaptations with reduced exercise intensity and volume. 

Please note that the exercise protocols may vary based on the individual's fitness level, age, and medical status. 

For resistance training, participants will follow a circuit of six exercises: bench press, triceps extension, leg press, leg curl, assisted pull-up, and assisted push-up. The resistance level will be adjusted according to the individual's fitness level and tolerance to ensure that each participant can properly manage the exercise effort. For the aerobic exercise, participants will perform treadmill walking or running at various speed and intensity levels, adjusted based on the participant's fitness level and tolerance. 

Please note that the research team members and certified fitness professionals will closely monitor and guide the participants throughout the exercise protocols.

Brief Summary

Microorganisms in the urine of urodynamic catheterized urinary tract obstruction patients are often unclear, and the proportion of these microorganisms is generally related to the blockage progression of urinary tract obstruction and even urinary tract stenosis. We can determine the severity of inflammation in patients with urinary tract obstruction by combining urine flora with urine culture and analysis of differential leukocyte count .However, clinical management of patients is usually based on bacterial cultures, which do not involve specific microbiological analysis. There is increasing evidence that inflammation in UTis is caused not only by the presence of microbes, but also by the immune response to their presence and products. In this study, we will take samples from 87 male and female patients aged 18-70 with lower urinary tract symptoms, enriched with patients with non-bacterial prostatitis, but without a urodynamic diagnosis of urinary tract obstruction or bladder obstruction to find out the pathogenic bacteria and pathogenic microorganisms that cause prostatitis. The relationship between urinary tract inflammation and the proportion and type of pathogenic bacteria will be discussed, so as to provide a new idea to improve the diagnosis and treatment of urinary tract obstruction and refractory non-bacterial prostatitis.

Prostate cancer has become one of the most common malignant tumors in men. As a result, its symptoms can be similar to those of chronic inflammation. Abstract:
Asthmatic obstructive airway disease develops during early childhood, but the factors affecting the disease onset have not been clarified. Thus, we conducted a case‐control study to evaluate the factors affecting childhood asthma on the basis of a prenatal and perinatal epidemiological study in Japan. We selected 383 cases with onset of asthmatic bronchitis or the diagnosis of asthma before the age of four years from a cohort of 173 infants who were enrolled for birth cohort study in 1991. The control group was made up of randomly selected 383 infants without childhood asthma, matched and individually paired with cases by sex and gestational age. We performed interviews of the mother via telephone and questioned them about socioeconomic status, prenatal and perinatal factors. We compared risk factors by the odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. The results revealed that asthmatic obstructive airway disease in infancy was significantly higher in infants with positive family history of asthma and in infants of mothers with higher levels of 2‐methoxyestrone (270 pg/d, OR (odds ratio) = 3.26, 95% CI (confidence interval) 1.04‐9.25), 2‐hydroxyestrone (133 pg/d, OR = 13.08, 95% CI 1.91‐89.07), 2‐naphthol (4140 ug/d, OR = 4.96, 95% CI 1.64‐15.02), and 2‐phenylphenol (236 ug/d, OR = 10.62, 95% CI 2.79‐98.26) in serum during the first trimester of pregnancy. These results suggest that maternal estrogen levels and perinatal factors are associated with risk of childhood asthma.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This experimental clinical trial of 16 weeks duration is intended to evaluate the safety and efficacy of 3,4-methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy at two different dosage levels for treatment of anxiety arising from chronic, treatment-resistant, post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).

Detailed Description
-----------------
This experimental clinical trial is intended to evaluate the safety and efficacy of 3,4-Methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA)-assisted psychotherapy at two different dosage levels for treatment of anxiety arising from chronic, treatment-resistant, PTSD. Subjects who qualify for the study will be screened for eligibility. Subjects who meet all of the eligibility criteria will be enrolled in the trial. Subjects will be assigned to one of two parallel groups following minimization, randomization, or assignment to reduce the number of subjects who do not meet all of the eligibility criteria. Group 1 will be assigned to receive two, 125-milligram (mg) doses of MDMA, while Group 2 will be assigned to receive two, 250-mg doses of MDMA. Each subject will consume the MDMA as the first of a series of three one-session experiences, each in a two-week period. Sessions 2 and 3 will occur in the same way, with the same number of doses of MDMA at the same dosage level. All MDMA sessions will be preceded by a preparatory screening and review. Session 1 and 3 will be followed by a review and debriefing session.

Official Title
-----------------
An Open, Randomized, Crossover Dose-Finding Investigation of 3,4-Methylenedioxy-methamphetamine (MDMA)-Assisted Psychotherapy for Treatment-Resistant Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PT

Introduction Achieving a sustained exercise habit is often difficult and requires behavior modification. Recent research has shown that personalization of exercise plans may be advantageous over individualized exercise plans. We present a comparison of the effects of individualized exercise plans and different types of personalization of exercise plans at the start and end of a 12‐week exercise intervention on fitness level and motivation among individuals who are sedentary or only occasionally exercise. Methods This open‐label parallel‐group randomized clinical trial recruited sedentary or rarely active men and women through flyers and social media. Three hundred and two (41 women, 231 men) participants were consecutively recruited and screened in the department of clinical sports medical science at Ghent University Hospital, Belgium, where they completed questionnaires and a fitness test including measurement of endurance and muscular strength. They were subsequently randomized to individualized exercise plans (Group 1), exercise plans adjusted to their fitness level (Group 2), or exercise plans adjusted to their genetic profile (Group 3) using genetic tests. Group 1 completed a control test at the 6‐ and 12‐week appointments only. Groups 2 and 3 received exercise plans adjusted to endurance and muscular strength results and genetic test results performed at the start and end of the exercise intervention, respectively. Results Groups 2 and 3 showed moderate‐to‐large increases in peak oxygen uptake, with Group 3 showing a larger effect size than Group 2 (+1.42 ± 1.52 mL⋅kg(‐1)⋅min(‐1)) vs. +0.88 ± 1.76 mL⋅kg(‐1)⋅min(‐1) (p=.001). In addition, they showed high levels of motivation and engagement in the exercise intervention. Genetic testing and exercise plan personalization revealed genetic polymorphisms and low fitness levels. The fitness tests revealed large interindividual differences. Conclusion Compared to individualized exercise plans, different types of personalization of exercise

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The Edison™ System is a newly-developed therapy device with an investigational new drug, using a completely novel energy source (HIFEm, a form of ultrasound) to target tissue, causing targeted molecular disruption that results in tissue death and necrosis. The HistoSonics Edison™ System is indicated for localized tumor ablation. HIFEm and histotripsy work to create a focused area of increased temperature and pressure in the tissue that leads to cell rupture, which is known as cavitation. In the case of the Edison™ System, the goal is to induce necrosis of the tumor while minimizing unintended damage to surrounding tissues. The Edison™ System will be used to ablate target lesions with a diameter of 3-5 cm through a multi-step process. Subjects will undergo CT-fluid perfusion imaging, MRI, and diagnostic biopsy followed by a diagnostic angiogram and a planning arteriogram. After the planning arteriogram and a temporary closure device is placed, subjects will undergo the Edison™ Histotripsy procedure(s), consisting of a maximum of three treatments in a single procedure session. Safety and Efficacy of the HistoSonics Edison™ System for the treatment of pancreatic adenocarcinoma will be evaluated by using MRI and other imaging techniques at 8 weeks, 12 weeks, and every 4 weeks until the tumor is ablated, or at least 3 months post-procedure.

Official Title
-----------------
The HistoSonics Edison™ System for Treatment of Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma Using Histotripsy - Pilot Clinical Trial

Conditions
-----------------
Pancreas Neoplasms, Ductal Adenocarcinoma of the Pancreas

Abstract:
INTRO: This study was conducted to evaluate the efficacy and safety of high strength oral antioxidant therapy with a mixed‐antioxidant cocktail in patients undergoing orthotopic liver transplantation (OLT).MATERIALS AND METHODS: Nineteen patients were enrolled in a prospective, double‐blind, placebo‐controlled trial using a random assignment schedule. Patients received oral antioxidants (pycnogenol, gamma‐lactoglutan [Nutricol], N‐acetyl‐cysteine, and vitamin E, n = 10) or placebo (n = 9) starting 2‐3 weeks before OLT. Perioperative complications, survival, cholestatic parameters, and oxidant‐reducing parameters were compared in the patients treated with the four antioxidants and in those patients who received the placebo.RESULTS: Five‐year survival was 80% (8/10) in the antioxidant group vs 33% (3/9) in the placebo group (p = 0.01). Intrahepatic and extraintestal cholelithiasis, acute rejection post OLT, and incidences of biliary strictures were reduced significantly by antioxidant therapy (p = 0.01). Decreases in glutathione, plasma iron levels, and malondialdehyde were observed in the patients receiving antioxidant therapy compared with the placebo group.CONCLUSIONS: Patients who underwent antioxidant therapy with the cocktail used in this study had improved survival, reduced complications, and lower levels of oxidative damage compared with the control group.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The HistoSonics Edison System is an energy delivery system that ablates or destroys selected tissues under direct visualization. Our hypothesis is that the HistoSonics Edison System is non-inferior to the Enzo FX (focused ultrasound) treatment in achieving ablation outcomes as measured by the proportion of patients with ablation failure at 12 months from baseline.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The primary endpoint is the proportion of patients with an ablation success defined as evidence of viable tumor at 12 months from baseline as determined by a blinded pathological review board based on imaging follow-up in an intention-to-treat analysis. Secondary endpoints include the proportion of patients with ablation failure at 12 months as measured by repeat imaging follow-up in an intention-to-treat population, the proportion of patients with adverse events, and the proportion of patients with device-related serious and non-serious adverse events, as applicable.

Study overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this clinical trial is to assess the safety and preliminary efficacy of the histotripsy-enhanced focused ultrasound (HT-FUS) system in treating patients with locally advanced or metastatic unresectable, radiofrequency ablation-ineligible, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) or cholangiocarcinoma. This is an open-label, single-center, single-arm, Phase II feasibility study. Patients will undergo initial HT treatment, followed by the administration of local ablation therapy and systemic chemotherapy over 3 months. Patients will be treated initially with up to two treatment sessions per week. Treatment will continue every 4-6 weeks until HCC progression or development of post-operative complication. Patients who experience HCC progression will continue to receive chemotherapy alone.

Detailed Description
-----------------
We intend to enroll up to 20 patients in this trial. Patients will be treated for an estimated total of 8-12 weeks. Patients may experience adverse events related to the procedure, such as pain, bruising, and post-operative complications. Overall, 20 patients will receive a total of up to 6-12 sessions of HT. Up to 72 weeks of follow-up will occur after the last HT or chemotherapy treatment, whichever occurs last. Patients will be evaluated at baseline and at each HT session for safety and treatment efficacy. Safety is based on recording adverse events and vital signs. Efficacy is based on objective response rate according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors 1.1 (RECIST 1.1) or modified mRECIST.

Official Title
-----------------
A Phase II Feasibility Study of Histotripsy-Enhanced Focused Ultrasound for Liver Cancer

Hepatocellular Carcinoma, Cholangiocarcinoma

Abstract:
PURPOSE: To propose and describe three new diagnostic tests for detection of bacterial respiratory pathogens in humans that use bacterial proteases to produce fluorescent cleavage products from fluorescently labeled protein substrates. These tests were developed based on our prior studies using in vitro assays. They are more accurate, reliable and rapid than the current laboratory techniques. METHODS: Nasopharyngeal specimens were collected from hospitalized children under 2 years of age. Each specimen was tested by three different methods; in vitro assays with labeled protein substrates, culture, and PCR. Fluorescence microscopy was employed for observation. RESULTS: The results of our in vitro assays coincided well with data from the other two culture‐based methods. With the use of fluorescent substrates, we successfully detected different kinds of bacterial proteases from 97% of isolates of P. aeruginosa, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae that were routinely cultured from patients. In general, our assay was more sensitive than culture, and was also successful on samples collected from patients whose throat swabs were negative. CONCLUSION: Using our assays, bacterial proteases from 30% of S. pneumoniae serotypes were also observed in some specimens, confirming the significance of the protease detection assays in the rapid and accurate diagnosis of respiratory tract infections.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is to determine whether the use of a continuous positive airway pressure device may improve sleep in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and obstructive sleep apnea.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Sleep disordered breathing (SDB) affects 50 - 70% of patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Up to 90% of patients with COPD have an abnormal respiratory pattern during sleep including periods of complete absence of breathing (apnea), periods of hypopnea, or periods of increased breathing effort. Compared to healthy controls, these features are more prevalent among patients with COPD as compared to healthy controls. In addition, COPD patients have significantly less effective chemoreflexes to low blood oxygen (hypoxia) during sleep compared to healthy controls. Poorly functioning chemoreflexes during sleep increases apnea frequency. The investigators have established a clinical trial to test the hypothesis that breathing a higher fraction of exhaled carbon dioxide (CO2) during sleep may improve sleep quality in patients with COPD. This study will enroll 12 patients with COPD during a baseline visit and study measurements will be performed in the sleep laboratory at night 2-4 days later. The main aims are to: measure the impact of breathing a higher fraction of CO2 on sleep quality determine whether the higher fraction of CO2 improves sleep quality and breathing patterns during sleep determine whether the higher fraction of CO2 improves arterial oxygenation and blood pressure during sleep

Perfect. The Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status is a scale used to evaluate a patient's physical condition and ability to tolerate treatment. A score of 0 indicates the patient has no symptoms and no signs of disease. A score of 1 indicates the patient has symptoms due to the presence of the disease, but they are still fully independent. A score of 2 indicates the patient requires some assistance with daily activities, a score of 3 indicates the patient is completely dependent, and a score of 4 indicates the patient is no longer able to take care of their daily personal needs. Patients who score 0-3 are considered suitable for study participation because they are expected to benefit from the treatments being evaluated in the trial. Background
=================
The purpose of this study is to determine whether the introduction of a proactive patient-centered follow-up system into the care of patients who have been treated at our institution for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) could result in a decrease in post-acute care (PAC) length of stay. Such a decrease could result in a lower overall health care cost and an improved quality of life for patients with ARDS and their caregivers.
We recently conducted a pilot study of a similar patient-centered follow-up system for patients with ARDS treated at our intensive care unit (ICU) during the first 6 months of the COVID-19 pandemic , which led to a significant decrease in PAC length of stay in survivors (i.e., 0 days, SD 2.6 vs. 0.5, SD 2.6, P = 0.002). However, a number of limitations made the effect of the intervention difficult to assess. A large proportion of patients discharged from the ICU did not receive follow-up at our institution, and it was not possible to exclude all patients who were discharged from the ICU to a location in a long-term care facility due to the study’s retrospective design. In addition, the timing of intervention was likely delayed for many patients due to the limitations of a retrospective study.
In this study, our primary aim is to determine whether the introduction of the proactive patient-centered follow-up system will reduce PAC length of stay for patients discharged to a location other than a long-term care facility, as compared to a control group consisting of patients who underwent ARDS treatment prior to the implementation of the system.
Methods and analysis

A total of 145 cases and 149 controls were randomly selected after a complete assessment of their medical history and the clinical stage of their disease. After complete cervical examination, the cases were selected on the basis of cytology grade. The same examination was carried out for the controls. There was a statistically significant difference in the frequency of the risk factors age, parity, multiple intercourse, previous sexually transmitted diseases (STD) and anal intercourse in cases. The frequency of the predisposing and preventing factors age, duration of sexual life, number of sexual partners, coital position and condom use was not significantly different between the two groups. The detection rate of cervical HPV was 8.8% in cases. It was 3.4% in controls and the difference was statistically significant. It was observed that among patients with HPV, 95.2% of those with grade III were positive for HPV, while 61.1% and 11.1% of patients with grades I and II were positive, respectively. In patients with HPV, a significant association was found between the grade of histological change, positive HPV and sexual transmission of HPV.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients undergoing endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD) have increased perioperative morbidity than those undergoing colonoscopy. Adequate hemostasis during endoscopic submucosal dissection will significantly prevent intraprocedural bleeding and post-procedural complications. A novel technique for hemostasis during endoscopy is the use of β-cyclodextrin-methyl methacrylate (CM) powder. This is a prospective and observational study that includes 80 patients with endoscopically resectable colorectal polyps undergoing ESD in our endoscopy unit. Primary outcome include immediate and delayed blood test results, and histologic results. The secondary outcome is to investigate the safety and efficacy of this novel hemostasis for ESD. All participating patients will be provided with a CM powder and apply it to the mucosal defect after ESD. Hemostasis will be evaluated using direct observation and vital signs. In addition, immediate and delayed blood test results will be evaluated. Histologic results after resection will also be investigated.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study seeks to explore the use of a topical application of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) as a treatment for periodontal flap dehiscence and fenestrations, also known as vertical root fractures. The researchers will follow participants for up to one year and evaluate the success of the intervention.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Despite being one of the most common periodontal surgeries, post-surgical dehiscence and fenestrations are relatively common. Platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) has recently been used for soft tissue regeneration techniques. Although there have been case reports and reports of clinical trials of PRF used for periodontal flap dehiscence and fenestrations, there are several limitations in the existing literature. This study seeks to evaluate the effectiveness and success rate of topical PRF application on post-operative defects after periodontal flap surgery and to follow the participants for up to one year to evaluate their success rates. To do this, the study will include consecutive patients aged 18 to 60 years with one or more posterior teeth requiring flap surgery for treatment of periodontal disease with pockets greater than 5 mm and vertical bone defects, and who have no other contraindications to participate in the study. The study will involve two stages. The first stage will be a pilot study of 10 participants who will receive PRF treatment. If successful, the second stage will involve a parallel randomized controlled trial of up to 100 participants with at least 50 receiving PRF treatment (intervention group) and 50 receiving conventional care, including an antibiotic washout and grafting of a resorbable collagen membrane, with a 3-month follow-up. Abstract:
Frequently, it is challenging to achieve an acceptable degree of visual acuity to complete the eye examination in a young child or in special circumstances. With the increasing importance of vision screening, the need for rapid and accurate vision screening tools that could be used in routine medical care is becoming ever more important. The purpose of this study was to provide some quantitative evidence for the validity of an alternative approach to vision screening to supplement the traditional tests. For 210 children and adolescents (mean age 9.1 years; range 4‐17), visual acuity was measured at an individual, comfortable viewing distance with a standard vision screening tool and with a new screening tool. The new screening tool, a printed and a handheld object, was placed against a background at increasing angles and distances from the child's dominant eye. The child could look at the screen and then could push a button when the image was no longer clearly identifiable. The results suggest that the new screening tool has acceptable validity as a supplementary screening test for use in school settings and when vision screening with the traditional method is not possible.

Abstract:
Background: The aim of this study was to retrospectively review patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) treated in an academic setting. Methods: Records of 481 patients diagnosed with mCRC from 1997 to 2014 were reviewed. Median follow‐up was 5.1 years. Results: Median patient age was 64 years, and 316 (65.5%) were males. The average number of prior chemotherapeutic regimens was 2.5, and the most common agents were infusional fluoropyrimidines (94.8%) followed by irinotecan (82.7%), oxaliplatin (75.1%), and cetuximab (25.5%). For the entire cohort, overall survival (OS) was 25.2 months. A total of 115 patients (24.0%) received targeted therapy alone, 16 patients (3.3%) received chemotherapy only, 314 patients (65.2%) received both modalities, and the remainder were not treated for their metastatic disease, but were either untreated or treated with investigational agents. Median OS for the entire cohort was 25.5 months, and OS was not statistically significant after adjustment for clinical covariates. Among those receiving targeted therapy alone, the group with EGFR inhibitor plus BRAF inhibitor was associated with a shorter OS (17.8 versus 44.1 months P<0.01). Conclusions: In this large and heterogeneous group of patients with mCRC, outcomes differed widely based on treatment regimens. This retrospective analysis found that targeted therapeutics can be equally effective when considering patients with or without chemotherapy as frontline therapy. The results also emphasize the importance to consider biomarkers at time of treatment selection.

The primary outcome measure is an increase in dystrophin expression in skeletal muscle biopsy samples. This measure is based on immunohistochemical analysis of the biopsy samples to determine the level of dystrophin expression. The increase in dystrophin expression can serve as a biomarker for the efficacy of the SGT-003 gene therapy.

The secondary outcome measure is the change in 6-minute walk distance (6MWD). This measure is based on a widely used functional assessment tool that evaluates the participant's ability to walk for distances of approximately 300 meters. The change in 6MWD can be used to evaluate the participant's ability to conduct normal daily activities.

 [/TITLE]

This is the summary of the BGM GL22 clinical trial, designed to evaluate the system accuracy of a novel blood glucose monitoring system (BGMS) in different glucose conditions.

 [/TITLE] 
[STUDY OBJECTIVE]
The aim of this study is to evaluate the system accuracy of a novel blood glucose measuring system (BGMS) using a validated glucose meter as the reference analytical method. The study compares the BGMS readings to the reference method using a glucose solution with 18 different glucose levels in each condition (hypoglycemic, eu- and hyperglycemic). This study primarily focuses on the comparison in each condition and aims to show that the BGMS is reliable for a variety of glucose levels in healthy participants. The study aims to demonstrate the clinical performance of the BGMS under different glucose conditions with a system accuracy of 20% or better.
 [/STUDY OBJECTIVE] 
[DESIGN/CONTRIBUTION OF THE INVESTIGATOR]
This is an interventional, monocentric, prospective clinical trial that provides no influence of any kind to the clinical performance, evaluation, or conclusions of the participants. In cooperation with the investigator, the sponsor will conduct a feasibility study to assess and demonstrate the system accuracy of the BGMS in different glucose conditions (hypo-, eu- and hyperglycemic). The results of the feasibility study will determine if the BGMS meets the requirements for further clinical trials with regard to system accuracy.

Abstract:
BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVE: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia can lead to postoperative atelectasis. We investigate whether the recruitment maneuver, performed after positive‐end‐expiratory pressure (PEEP), can improve oxygenation after reversing the muscle paralysis in patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. METHODS: Fifty patients who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy were randomly assigned to either the recruitment maneuver group or the control group (25 patients each). After the muscle relaxant was stopped, the recruitment maneuver was performed at 40 cmH2O for 40 seconds followed by 5 cmH2O for at least 2 minutes in the recruitment group. All patients in the control group were ventilated with the same pressure. The difference in oxygenation between the two groups was assessed immediately after stopping the muscle paralysis and after the end of the procedure. RESULTS: The recruitment maneuver did not show any significant difference in arterial oxygen partial pressure or SpO2 from baseline to the end of the recovery period. CONCLUSIONS: A recruitment maneuver after reversing muscle paralysis did not improve oxygenation in patients after a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Copyright © 2017 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.

BACKGROUND: Anemia, a common occurrence in the elderly, is a risk factor for developing hypertension. Its prevalent in community‐dwelling elderly persons, who may not reach optimal BP control through lifestyle measures.AIMS: This study aimed at assessing the safety and effect of hemidilution in hematocrit (Hct) ≥45% on BP, the prevalence of hypotension, and the dose of antihypertensive medication in hypertensive elderly patients with untreated anemia.METHODS AND RESULTS: Elderly patients with hypertension, anemia, and Hct ≥45% were recruited. Patients were randomly allocated to hemodilution and conventional management. Hemodilution was performed by either exchange transfusion (group 1: 30% increase in plasma volume) or dilution (group 2: 5% increase in plasma volume) with a colloid‐rich hemodilution volume determined by the blood viscosity difference between baseline and after hemodilution.CONCLUSIONS: Hemodilution in patients with isolated anemia can decrease BP without the risk of hypotension or the need for an increased use of antihypertensive drugs.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Endocarditis involving the tricuspid valve continues to remain an important cause of major morbidity and mortality, associated with significant mortality despite appropriate antibiotic therapy. The overall mortality of endocarditis at 6 months is 15-30%. This prospective randomized controlled trial of early tricuspid valve surgery vs medical management of endocarditis, performed by the same tricuspid valve surgical approach utilized at Stanford, compares early surgery vs medical management and assesses its impact on clinical risk factors and outcomes in patients with active tricuspid valve endocarditis without complications.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Despite improved diagnostic and therapeutic strategies, endocarditis involving the tricuspid valve in humans continues to remain an important cause of major morbidity and mortality. Tricuspid valve surgery is associated with high procedural risks and is often precluded by the presence of systemic infection, low cardiac output, and other comorbid conditions often associated with tricuspid endocarditis. Because of these associated risk factors, current recommendations for the treatment of tricuspid valve endocarditis in humans state that surgical treatment should be deferred for all patients early in the course of disease, with few exceptions. The use of appropriate antimicrobial therapy has improved the outcomes associated with bacterial endocarditis of the tricuspid valve, yet tricuspid valve surgery remains a necessity in about 60% of patients due to persistent abscess formation, systemic infection, endocarditis despite adequate antimicrobial therapy, persistent sepsis, hemolytic anemia, or ventricular failure. Intervention
=================
The Intervention is Transluminal Tricuspid Annuloplasty Device for the treatment of severe functional TR. TricValve Device is CE marked and FDA approved. This device is intended to be used as treatment for severe functional tricuspid regurgitation. The TricValve Device is composed of a pair of polymer anchors, each containing a metal wire helix. The wire helixes each expand from within the lumen of the right ventricle by means of a delivery system. The TricValve device is positioned under fluoroscopic guidance across the tricuspid annulus and the anchors are placed on the ventricular side of the tricuspid annulus. The two anchors lock together and exert radial force against the tricuspid annulus, bringing the leaflets and annulus closer together, thus treating tricuspid regurgitation.

(TCI) according to prespecified criteria. This exploratory study will assess, for the first time, TTS performance in a homogenous population with severe TR, including the safety, efficacy, and utility of the TTS in this particular patient population .

Detailed Description
-----------------
This study will involve implantation of the TricValve System (TTS), developed by TCI, in 4 patients (N=4), in the setting of high risk surgical subjects or patients that are either too high risk for open heart surgery or are not eligible for another available device. The TTS is a transcatheter tricuspid valve replacement (TTVR) device being developed by TCI as a solution to severe tricuspid regurgitation, which currently affects 10-15% of the population and has limited treatment options. TTS is a transcatheter replacement approach that is currently in development in order to avoid open heart surgery and provide a better outcome and quality of life for patients suffering from severe tricuspid regurgitation. This proposed study is aimed at assessing the safety and functional effectiveness of the device prior to clinical use. All patients will be followed for 30 days post implantation and adverse events, mortality, complications and overall safety are evaluated. Follow-up

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to estimate the prevalence of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) in young adults.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Rhinosinusitis is an inflammation or swelling of the lining of the nose, which can affect your breathing and sense of smell. It can be either acute (short-term) or chronic (long-term). Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a common health problem, especially in adults. However, it is unknown how much of a problem CRS is in young adults. This study is designed to find out how many young adults have CRS. We will investigate whether or not patients with CRS seen in a primary care setting can take part in a 3-month study that includes a video phone. Those patients (and his or her parent or legal guardian) may be eligible to participate in the study if they are between the ages of 18-35 and have sinus symptoms for more than 12 weeks and are willing to participate in the study and take study medications. Young adults who enroll in the study will be given a short questionnaire, which will be used to determine how many young adults in the area of interest have CRS. They will also have blood drawn when they visit a clinic for routine blood tests.

Official Title
-----------------
Estimation of the Prevalence of Chronic Rhinosinusitis Among Young Adults Using Data From the Primary Health Care Clinics in South Korea

Intervention
=================
The investigators have developed novel synthetic bacteria, derived from the faecal samples of healthy human patients. These bacteria are designed to resemble natural gut microbiota and are cultured in a sterile environment to ensure their safety and consistency. The investigators will administer one capsule per day orally to 20 participants, each containing approximately 7.5 x 109 of synthetic bacteria, for two consecutive weeks. Participants will be monitored throughout the study to ensure their safety and well-being. Each participant will receive two doses of the intervention, separated by a two-week washout period.

Drug

Primary outcome measure
=================
The investigators will assess changes in the gut microbiota of the participants by measuring the abundance and composition of their gut microbiota through 16S ribosomal ribonucleic acid (rRNA) gene sequencing. The primary outcome measure will be changes in the relative abundance of specific gut microbiota within the participants. The investigators will analyze the microbiota data to determine the correlation between the changes in the gut microbiota and the clinical outcomes of the participants.
E.5.2 Secondary outcome measures: Secondary outcome measures include changes in the abundance and composition of other types of microbiota, including stool-associated bacteria, serum metabolomic profiles, and clinical outcomes such as body weight, blood pressure, serum levels of lipids, liver function, and immune function. The investigators will also assess the safety and tolerability of taking the synthetic bacteria.

Dear Dr. M.A.D:

I have read your manuscript entitled “The Efficacy of Fingolimod and its effect on the Quality of Life of Patients with Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis Treated in the Real World Setting: a Prospective Follow-up Registry After Completion of the ASCEND3 Study.” I am pleased to inform you that we would like to invite you to submit a revised version of the manuscript that addresses the points raised during the review process.
In this retrospective analysis, the authors investigated the effect of fingolimod treatment on the quality of life of patients with RRMS after completion of the placebo-controlled trial ASCEND3. The authors report that patients treated with fingolimod experienced significant improvements in quality of life after 6 months post-treatment as measured by the FSS and EQ-5D-5L, and that these improvements were sustained for up to 4 years post-treatment. Despite the high number of dropouts, the data seems to indicate a positive effect of fingolimod treatment on quality of life in real-world settings. However, several issues were raised during the review process which need to be addressed. The manuscript should be significantly revised to improve the scientific rigor and clinical significance of the reported findings. The main concern is the lack of a control group and the questionable generalizability of the results to other patient populations. The authors should also consider including more data regarding the characteristics of the patients included in the analysis and the duration of treatment in the real-world setting.
Please submit your revised manuscript by Dec 31 2023 11:59PM. If you will need more time than this to complete your revisions, please reply to this message or contact the journal office at jneurosci.neurosci@pleasemedia.com. When you're ready to submit your revision, log on to https://www

Abstract:
In this placebo‐controlled, prospective, randomized trial, we investigated the safety and efficacy of amino acid administration in patients who undergo transurethral microlithotripsy (TUMT) with pneumatic lithotripsy for the treatment of calcium ureteral stone (CUS). Thirty‐eight patients who underwent TUMT were randomized to receive amino acid infusion over 8 h or 4 h before surgery or 4 h before and after surgery (group C). Twenty‐six patients who underwent surgery without amino acid administration and 40 healthy subjects in our hospital were used as control (groups NC, PH, PH). The visual analogue scale (VAS) was assessed in all preoperative, postoperative, and 24 h after TUMT. The patients were allowed immediate hospital discharge after completing VAS. The amino acid levels before TUMT, 30 min, 2, 4, and 6 after surgery, and at 24 h after surgery were measured in 3 groups. Significant differences were observed in the serum amino acid levels and VAS score between 3 groups after surgery. A significant decrease in amino acid levels was observed in groups C‐PH 30 min after surgery (p < 0.05). Significant differences were observed in the VAS scores in groups C‐PH 24 h after surgery (p < 0.01). Group C‐PH has significantly higher VAS scores than the NC group for 24 h after surgery. A significant difference was observed in the VAS score between C‐PH and NC groups at 2, 18, and 24 h after surgery (p < 0.01). The results of this trial suggest that the administration of amino acids before and after TUMT can reduce postoperative pain and improve recovery. We conclude that amino acid administration has an

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is designed to examine the effects of a novel combination of therapies on the heart muscle in patients with heart failure due to damage from coronary artery disease (CAD). It will consist of approximately 30-60 patients, will be done at Mount Sinai Hospital and St. Michael's Hospital in Toronto, and will span over a period of 5 years (including 2 years of participant enrolment and 1 year of follow-up for each participant). Approximately 5 or 6 visits will occur during the year prior to receiving the study drugs, and once-a-month visits for 6 months after receiving study drugs. Participants will also be asked to attend one visit every 6 months for approximately 2 years after the last visit.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to examine the effects of two medications, metformin and L-carnitine, on the heart muscle in patients with heart failure due to damage of the heart muscle secondary to blockage of the arteries supplying blood to the heart (coronary artery disease). Metformin is a commonly used medication in the treatment of Type 2 diabetes, and L-carnitine is a naturally occurring substance that is needed by the heart muscle to function properly. We will administer metformin plus L-carnitine, or placebo plus L-carnitine, to all participants. We expect that the heart muscle will improve with less scar tissue in participants receiving metformin plus L-carnitine, compared with participants receiving placebo.

Official Title
-----------------
A Randomized Double-Blind Crossover Trial of Metformin in Combination With L-Carnitine on Cardiac Health of Patients With Coronary Artery Disease

Conditions
-----------------
Coronary Artery Disease

Intervention / Treatment
-----------------
* Drug: Metformin combined with L-Carnitine
* Drug: Placebo combined with L-C

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to examine the safety and efficacy of the NK11572 antigenic cancer vaccine in combination with the immune checkpoint inhibitors.

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to examine the safety and efficacy of the NK11572 antigenic cancer vaccine in combination with the immune checkpoint inhibitors (pembrolizumab). This study is a Phase 1a/1b, open-label, dose escalation study. Participants will receive the NK11572 vaccine intramuscularly (IM) combined with pembrolizumab intravenously (IV) every 3 weeks for two cycles. The study will enroll approximately 18 adult participants. 3 dose groups (n=6 for each group) will be evaluated in the Phase 1a dose escalation portion of the study. In the Phase 1b portion of the study, 6 additional participants will be enrolled in the 15 mg dose group for a total of 12 participants. Participants will be followed for safety and efficacy for approximately 2 years.

Official Title

A Multi-center, Open Label, Phase 1a/1b, Multiple Ascending Dose Study of the Safety and Efficacy of NK-11572 Vaccine to Be Given in Combination With Pembrolizumab in Advanced Solid Tumor Cancers

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The goal of this study is to compare the effects of aerobic exercise (AE) versus no additional activity (control) versus low level resistance training (LR) exercise on glucose homeostasis in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Exercise has an important influence on the glycemic response to nutritional challenges. The primary endpoint of this study is to determine the effect of 16 wk of aerobic exercise (AE) versus no additional activity (control) versus low level resistance training (LR) exercise on glucose homeostasis in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes in a supervised experimental setting. The secondary aim is to determine the effect of the three exercise paradigms on other metabolic and fitness parameters including cardiorespiratory fitness/VO2max, musculoskeletal strength, body composition, fasting profile, and insulin sensitivity. Measurement of circulating biomarkers, particularly cytokines, as well as vascular endothelial function will be conducted throughout the duration of the study to explore mechanistic pathways.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The primary objective of this study is to assess the pharmacokinetic (PK) and pharmacodynamic (PD) profiles of 90Y-ZW25 in subjects with extensive breast cancer, and, in addition, to evaluate the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) for 90Y-ZW25.

Detailed Description
-----------------
This is a Phase I, open-label, multicenter, dose de-escalation study of ZW25 (anti-her2 antibody) labeled with the BBB emitting radionuclide 90Y to determine the safety of 90Y-ZW25 in participants with locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer. The primary endpoint is determination of the maximal tolerated dose (MTD)/recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of 90Y-ZW25 based on DLT. Secondary endpoints include determination of the half-life of 90Y-ZW25, characterization of anti-tumor activity, characterization of potential tumor cell killing and tumor cell death as measured by PD indicators, and measurement of 90Y-ZW25 biodistribution as measured by uptake on SPECT/CT and ex vivo gamma counting.

-----------------

Abstract:
Introduction‐ We aimed to review the clinical efficacy of anti‐TNFalpha monotherapy with tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (TNFis) in rheumatic diseases in terms of efficacy and safety. Methods‐ A literature search was performed on PubMed, Scopus, and international conferences from 2012 to 2021. Studies focusing on the efficacy and safety of TNFis, such as infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, and golimumab monotherapy, were reviewed. Results‐ TNF monotherapy significantly suppresses the signs and symptoms of rheumatic diseases. However, there is not enough data on safety‐related events, including infusion‐related reactions (IRRs), tuberculosis (TB), and serious infections. Conclusion‐ Anti‐TNFis are safe, but monitoring for adverse events and the development of vaccines to prevent IRRs and TB are crucial to improve TNF monotherapy use.

Study design
