Randomization: Randomized, Blinding: Double blinded, Placebo: Not used, Assignment: Parallel, Purpose: Prevention, Randomization description: Block randomization is defined as a method of randomly assigning subjects (according to the block size) to experimental or control groups so that at any time, the next subject to enter the trial has the same chance of being assigned to either group. In such a way, two of the groups may have a disproportional number of subjects in the beginning, due to randomization. Accordingly, in this study, in order to equalize the number of individuals in the intervention group with the number of individuals in the control group, we use the block size of 4, and each block has only one study group. In this way, in the first block, one participant is assigned to the intervention and control group. In the second block, two subjects are assigned to the intervention group and one is assigned to the control group. In the third block, only one person is assigned to the intervention group, but two people are assigned to the control group. This process continues until the last block of 4 people in the intervention group and the last block of 4 people in the control group.

Intervention
=================
Intervention 1: Intervention group: Individuals in the intervention group will receive the study drug (Ozayl®). They will need to take 2 soft gel capsules daily. In this group, the drug will be given to them in two periods: The first period of two weeks, in which the number of 4 capsules will be given to each person, and in the second period, all persons in the intervention group will receive 2 capsules daily. Intervention 2: Control group: Control individuals who do not receive the drug will use a placebo. As similar to the intervention group, in the first period, each person will receive 4 placebo capsules. In the second period, each person will receive 2 placebo capsules daily.

Introduction
Ebola virus disease (EVD) is a severe, frequently fatal disease in humans, and the 2014 outbreak in West Africa was the largest to date, with over 28,000 cases (1). The approved vaccine against EVD (rVSVΔG-ZEBOV, Merck & Co, Inc., Kenilworth, NJ, USA) is a replication-competent, non-attenuated, recombinant vesicular stomatitis virus expressing Ebola virus glycoprotein, which has been shown to be safe and immunogenic in various clinical trials (2–4). Currently, the vaccine is recommended for administration to individuals at potential occupational risk for Ebola virus exposure (5–7). However, as there are no established guidelines for long-term protection after 3 doses of the vaccine, individuals with previous vaccination may require reinfection or booster vaccination to ensure continuous protection.
To evaluate the safety and immunogenicity of a single-dose heterologous vaccination regimen of rVSVΔG-ZEBOV and ChAdOx1 nCoV-19, an approved vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, an ongoing study was conducted in the DR Congo (ClinicalTrials.gov, NCT05164550). In this report, we present the results of the interim analysis for the primary and secondary endpoints of safety and humoral immune response, respectively.
Design

Abstract:
Dose‐dependent effects of naloxone and fentanyl on the inhibition of central respiratory depression caused by morphine, pethidine, and alfentanil in rhesus monkeys.1749‐1988. A total of 36 rhesus monkeys were randomly assigned to 48 groups (9 groups for each drug). The results demonstrated that naloxone, 10 mg/kg IV, caused complete reversal of the respiratory depressant effect of morphine (up to 2 mg/kg), but only partial reversal of the morphine effect at higher dose levels. Naloxone (6.25 and 12.5mg/kg) partially reversed the respiratory depression induced by pethidine (4.2 and 8.4 mg/kg), but did not significantly affect the depression induced by alfentanil (4 or 8 micrograms/kg). In addition, a total of 5 groups (10 monkeys) were also studied with respect to antagonism of naloxone. Naloxone (0.5‐4mg/kg) caused a dose‐dependent reversal of respiratory depression induced by pethidine, but did not restore normal respiration at an opioid concentration of 8.4 micrograms/ml (12.5 mg/kg). Naloxone antagonized the respiratory depressant effect of alfentanil regardless of antagonist dose, with complete reversal noted at 4 micrograms/kg, and partial reversal noted at 0.5 and 2.0 micrograms/kg.

Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age:

- For former PELISTAD participants: ≥6 to <15 years of age at the time of signing the informed consent.

- Applicable to new participants only: Have active lesions on the upper limbs or lower limbs (including trunk, if needed), with severity for lesion erythema or edema/papulation ≥2 at screening on the 0 to 3 scale of the ISS.
- Applicable to all participants: Should have a non-lesional (normal looking) skin area 4 cm from the edge of the lesional area. If unable to identify non-lesional skin 4 cm from the lesional area, it is acceptable to identify normal looking skin as close to the lesion as possible.

3. Weight:
- Body weight ≥15 kg at screening.

Exclusion Criteria:
1. Medical conditions:
- Skin conditions other than AD that can confound assessments in the area of TEWL assessments in the opinion of the Investigator (i.e., skin atrophy, ichthyosis, tinea infection, contact dermatitis).
- Cracked, crusted, oozing, or bleeding AD lesions in the designated lesional assessment area leaving insufficient skin that is adequate for TEWL assessments.
- Hypersensitivity to the active substance or to any of the excipients of dupilumab.
- Ocular disorder that, in the opinion of the Investigator, could adversely affect the individual's risk for study participation.
- Severe concomitant illness(es) that, in the Investigator's judgment, would adversely affect the participant's participation in the study.
- History of hypersensitivity reaction to skin tape or adhesives used in tape strip discs.

2. Prior/concomitant therapy:
- Treatment with any investigational medication other than dupilumab within 16 weeks or within 5 half-lives (if known) prior to Day 1, whichever is longer.
- Systemic AD treatment, cyclosporine A (CsA), systemic corticosteroids, azathioprine (AZA), methotrexate (MTX), mycophenolate mofetil (MMF), or Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors or phototherapy within 4 weeks of baseline.
- Topical AD treatment within 1 week of baseline. Face and neck may be treated with topical steroids during the washout period if approved by the Investigator.
- Participants who received a live vaccine within 4 weeks of baseline.

3. Prior/concurrent clinical study experience:
- Current participation in another investigational or interventional clinical study.

Certainly! Here are the full criteria for your review:
Inclusion criteria:
1. Patients with histologically or cytologically confirmed advanced or metastatic solid tumors who have disease progression after treatment with available therapies for their disease that are known to confer clinical benefit.
2. Have measurable disease per RECIST 1.1 as assessed by the local site investigator/radiology.
3. Accessible tumor tissue available for fresh biopsy or being considered for tumor biopsy according to the treating institution's guidelines and willing to undergo a new biopsy if not clinically contraindicated.
4. Performance status: Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance score 0-1.
5. Must have recovered from all adverse events (AEs) due to previous therapies to grade ≤1 toxicity.
6. Organ function: Have adequate organ function as defined during screening and prior to first SOT201 dose.

Exclusion criteria:
1. Known clinically relevant intolerability or severe hypersensitivity to prior anti PD-1 or anti-PD-L1 agent therapy.
2. Prior exposure to drugs that are agonists or antagonists of specific interleukins.
3. Prior systemic anti-cancer therapies within specific timeframes.
4. Predicted life expectancy ≤3 months.
5. Clinically significant cardiac abnormalities.
6. Active autoimmune diseases or immunodeficiency.
7. Active central nervous system metastases and/or carcinomatous meningitis.
8. History of pneumonitis/interstitial lung disease.
9. Active infection requiring systemic therapy.
10. History or current evidence of any condition, therapy, or laboratory abnormality that might confound the results of the trial.

Abstract:
One aspect of the present project included an in vivo exposure program for 67% of children who qualified for outpatient mental health treatments. The goal of this program was to provide children with anxiety symptoms a safe opportunity to confront their fears in the community. This study examined the efficacy of the exposure program using a single‐case ABAB design. Six children (five girls and one boy) between the ages of 5 and 7 who met DSM‐IV criteria for Specific Phobia were randomly assigned to either an exposure group (n = 3) or delayed exposure control group (n = 3). Children in the exposure group received parent‐guided exposure training in the first phase of the study, followed by parent‐guided child exposure in the second phase. Children in the control group were initially observed with parents in community settings. The following week, parents in the control group received written instructions to gradually provide guided exposure opportunities at home. Results indicated that parent‐guided exposure training and implementation of community‐based, child exposure for phobias was more successful than was delivery of exposure training and encouragement to provide at‐home exposure.

In this clinical study the researchers aim to determine the efficacy of an alternative medicine formulation compared with placebo in aiding recovery in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The researchers aim to achieve this by testing the efficacy of the study product to: reduce irritability and hyperactivity; improve social behaviour; improve communication skills; improve sensory integration; improve fine and gross motor skills; improve self-help activities; and improve daily living skills (such as dressing and food preparation). To further evaluate the safety and tolerability of the study product in children with ASD, as well as to understand the mechanism of action and the pharmacokinetic (PK) profile of the active ingredient, the researchers will also investigate these aspects throughout the study. 

The planned study will comprise a 12-week (3 months) double-blind clinical trial. During the study, subjects will receive either the investigational product (IP) or placebo and the results will be evaluated by clinical investigators and caregivers. The study aims to recruit 40 participants. Participants will be randomised into two groups; 20 participants will be administered with the IP and 20 participants will be given the placebo. The allocation to receive either the IP or placebo will be on a 1:1 ratio, meaning that for each participant receiving the IP, another participant will receive the placebo. 
The primary objective of the study is to demonstrate equivalence of the IP to placebo in relation to the improvement of the social responsiveness scale (SRS) score. The primary objective will be established on the basis of an observed difference of 1 standard deviation (SD) in the change from baseline score. The secondary objectives are to assess the efficacy of the IP compared with the placebo in relation to improvements in other clinical scales and the safety and tolerance of the IP in 40 children with autism. 
The main clinical scales that will be used are the Autism Treatment Evaluation Checklist - Child (ATEC), Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales II (VABS), the Pediatric Autism Rating Scale (PARS), the Aberrant Behavior Checklist (ABC) and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL). These scales will be used to evaluate the participant's social behaviour, communication skills, sensory integration, motor skills and self-help activities

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to find out if a personalized approach using a blood test can improve the amount of time that people with breast cancer live. In this study, participants will be randomized (like flipping a coin) to one of two groups. The group assigned to the experimental arm will get the standard of care that is currently given to patients. Those in the experimental arm will also be given a blood sample. The blood sample will be tested in a specialized laboratory to determine if special cells (also known as cells that fight infection) in their blood are present. If they are, it will mean that the white blood cells are helping to destroy cancer. If special cells are not present, it could mean that the white blood cells are helping to protect the tumor.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to assess which dosing schedule should be used for the chemotherapy portion of a combined chemoradiotherapy study. We evaluated cisplatin dosing schedules of 3, 4, 5‐day infusions on a 3‐, 4‐, and 5‐day continuous infusion schedule for concurrent Cisplatin and radiation therapy. The 3‐day infusion and 5‐day continuous infusion schedules showed similar pharmacokinetic behavior and toxicity. Patients randomized to a 4‐day continuous infusion (CI) schedule of Cisplatin experienced dose limiting bone marrow toxicity, but there was no difference in radiation therapy treatment delay or completion. We recommend 4‐day intermittent CI cisplatin infusion for concurrent chemoradiotherapy due to the increased convenience and lower cost.

groundtruth: Great! The first inclusion criterion is the provision of a signed and dated informed consent form. This ensures that participants are fully aware of the study procedures, risks, and benefits, and have given their voluntary consent to participate.

The second criterion is the stated willingness to comply with all study procedures and availability for the duration of the study. We need participants who are committed to following the study protocol and attending all required visits and assessments to gather accurate and reliable data.
The third criterion is that participants must be male or female and at least 18 years of age. This ensures that participants are adults who can make informed decisions about their healthcare.

The fourth criterion is a pathologically proven diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx of any AJCC 8th edition stage. This specifies the type of cancer and its stage to ensure that the study focuses on a specific population with a similar disease profile.

The fifth criterion states that participants must be eligible for and planning to receive definitive treatment or adjuvant treatment with radiotherapy. This is important as participants must be suitable candidates for the treatment being investigated in the trial to assess its safety and effectiveness.

The sixth criterion allows for the inclusion of participants who are receiving concurrent systemic anticancer therapy, such as chemotherapy or immunotherapy, for oropharyngeal cancer. This accounts for additional treatments that participants may be receiving, which could impact the outcomes of the study.

The seventh criterion is the ECOG Performance Status of 0-2. This ensures that participants have a good performance status, indicating that they are able to carry out daily activities without significant limitations. This is important as it may affect their ability to tolerate treatment and participate in the study.

The eighth criterion specifies that participants must be p16 positive HPV as determined by NavDx and immunohistochemistry. This is important as the HPV status may influence the response to treatment and outcomes in HPV-related cancers.

The ninth criterion is for females of reproductive potential. They must agree to use adequate contraception during radiation treatment and for 6 months (or more if applicable based on other medications) after the end of radiation treatment. This aims to prevent pregnancy during and after treatment, as radiation therapy may pose risks to a developing fetus.

The exclusion criteria are used to identify factors that would make a participant ineligible for the study. They help ensure the safety of participants and the integrity of the study results. Shall we go through them?

The first exclusion criterion is evidence of distant metastatic disease. Participants with metastatic disease may have different treatment requirements and outcomes, which could confound the results of the study.

The second criterion states that participants with a prior history of radiotherapy to the head and/or neck are excluded. Previous radiation therapy may impact the response to subsequent treatment and increase the risk of side effects.

The third criterion is that participants who had surgery for oropharyngeal cancer within 8 months of enrollment are excluded. Recent surgery may affect the ability to receive radiation therapy and impact the outcomes of the study.

The fourth criterion states that participants with a diagnosis of T3-4 and/or N+ disease must have plans to receive concurrent chemotherapy. This ensures that participants with more advanced disease receive the appropriate standard of care treatment.

The fifth criterion is a diagnosis of a current or prior invasive malignancy, except non-melanoma skin cancer, unless the participant has been disease-free for at least 3 years. Participants with a history of other cancers may have different treatment responses and outcomes, which could confound the results of the study.

The sixth criterion states that prisoners are excluded from the study. Prisoners may have limited access to healthcare and may not represent the general population, affecting the generalizability of the study results.

The seventh criterion specifies known contraindications to head and neck radiation therapy, such as ataxia telangiectasia or scleroderma. Participants with contraindications to the treatment being investigated may be at increased risk of complications.

The eighth criterion excludes participants who are pregnant or lactating. Pregnancy and lactation may pose risks to the fetus or infant during radiation therapy, and the effects of treatment on pregnancy outcomes are not well understood.

The next criterion is the exclusion of participants with active or severe co-morbidities. Participants with significant medical conditions may be at higher risk of complications during treatment, affecting the safety and outcomes of the study.

The last criterion states that participants with a tobacco smoking history of 10 pack years or greater, or ≥ 20 pack years if smoking cessation occurred at least 1 year prior to enrollment, are excluded. Smoking history may impact treatment response and outcomes, as smoking can affect the efficacy of radiation therapy.

Yes, there is one more. The final criterion is the exclusion of participants currently using antineoplastic drugs for other malignancies. Participants receiving treatment for other cancers may have different treatment responses and outcomes, which could confound the results of the study.

Abstract:
Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) rupture of the knee can produce considerable loss of proprioception function, which increases the risk of subsequent recurrent injuries and chronic knee symptoms. However, rehabilitation is currently an empirical therapy for restoring knee proprioception function after ACL surgery. This study aimed to compare the effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) versus electrotherapy on proprioception in patients with ACL rupture after reconstruction. This study was conducted in accordance with the standards of the Declaration of Helsinki in 2020 and by the local ethical committee in Iran (IR.KMU.REC.1398.115). Thirty‐seven patients with ACL rupture after reconstructive surgery were involved in the study and randomly placed into two groups (the PNF group of 18 patients and the EMG group of 19 patients). The patients in the PNF group were treated using PNF stretching techniques, and the EMG group was treated using electrical stimulation of the quadriceps femoris muscles. The treatment was given three times a week for three weeks, and pre‐ and post‐treatment assessments included the time to reach maximum movement with active joint movement, knee range of motion (ROM), and modified Tegner activity score. Data were analyzed using SPSS software. Findings showed that, after treatment, proprioception function scores compared to pre‐treatment levels had significantly increased in both groups (p˂0.001). In addition, the PNF group showed a significant increase in proprioception function scores compared to the EMG group (p = 0.028). PNF stretching can more effectively improve proprioception function in patients with anterior cruciate ligament rupture than traditional electrotherapy after surgery.

Abstract:
Background: SARS‐CoV‐2‐associated cytokine storm syndrome results in hypercytokinemia and increased serum ferritin despite normal or iron‐deficient transferrin saturation. We describe the first reported experience with the potential efficacy and safety of intravenous iron therapy in hospitalized patients with COVID‐19. Methods: Patients admitted to our hospital with COVID‐19 from March 27 to June 12, 2020, were included. We applied a preplanned, single center, cohort design with a retrospective chart review and propensity score matching to compare early and late cases of hospitalized COVID‐19 patients who received oral or intravenous iron for worsening anemia and/or increased serum ferritin. Results: 12 of 304 patients in our cohort received either oral or intravenous iron therapy. Eight patients in the matched analysis group and ten patients in the unmatched comparison group underwent iron therapy, ‐ one patient in the matched group received both intravenous and oral iron therapy. These patients received a median of 1.3 ± 3 (1–6) infusions of a median dose of 191mg (91, 200, 400) of iron as ferric carboxymaltose, and a median of 200mg (100) of oral iron (Sucraid CR) as sulfate‐free, ferrous carboxymaltose. The propensity‐matched average length of hospital stay was 7.5 and 12.4 ±13 (10,16, 34) for participants in the 2 groups, respectively. There were no differences in the outcomes of inpatient COVID‐19 disease between the 2 groups. Four or 5 patients in the 2 groups, respectively, developed worsening or new‐onset atrial fibrillation. Two patients experienced cardiac arrest. Both developed worsening atrial fibrillation, the patient in the matched analysis group did not survive and the patient in the comparison group survived. Brief Summary

The aim of the present study is to determine how the addition of the investigational medicine can help to prevent preterm birth in an animal model. This can help to develop new medications that can improve pregnancy, health and survival outcomes for premature babies.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Background - preterm birth is estimated to occur in at least 1 in 10 pregnancies worldwide and remains one of the most significant causes of perinatal morbidity and mortality worldwide*. Despite an increase in understanding of the physiological processes underlying the pathophysiology of human preterm birth over the past decades, the incidence has not changed significantly over the past 30 years and is likely to rise due to the ageing of the population and improved obstetric surveillance**. Approximately 10% of preterm births are without an identifiable cause. A higher percentage of women that were primiparous or with a history of preterm birth, placental damage, uterine abnormalities, or chorioamnionitis are at higher risk for spontaneous labor, with the overall likelihood of developing a complication dependent on the number of factors that are present (multiparity, chorioamnionitis, abnormal placentation or abnormalities of uterine contractility)**. The present study can therefore contribute significantly to our understanding on gestational mechanisms underlying pregnancy and preterm labor, and thus, provide knowledge on how to improve pregnancy, health, and survival outcomes of preterm babies. Methods - the present study will be performed in non-pregnant (n=6) and pregnant female (n=6) Sprague Dawley pigs. The pregnant females are implanted with an Oocyte Stimulation Induction Pill and bred with a male pig to achieve pregnancy. After one month of pregnancy, pregnancy is confirmed by ultrasound and endometrial biopsy, followed by collection of vaginal samples, blood samples, and endometrial biopsies to investigate cytokine levels. Afterwards, the investigational medicine will be administered via a subcutaneous (SC) injection. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The major reason for discontinuation in the maintenance therapy for the renal function decline associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) is the side effects. The investigators aim to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the sitagliptin once a day versus DPP4 inhibitor saxagliptin in Chinese type 2 diabetes patients with normal or impaired renal function. This is a 26 week, randomized, prospective, open-label, single-center study. A total of 150 subjects who are newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes patients aged 18-70 years, whose baseline HbA1c≥ 7.5% to ≤ 10% and serum creatinine ≤128.6 umol/L will be randomly divided into A group or B group at a ratio of 1:1. The subjects in A group will receive sitagliptin 100mg once a day for 26 weeks, while the subjects in B group will receive Saxagliptin 5mg once a day. The investigators observe the changes in the primary and secondary outcomes during the treatment period. It is hypothesized that sitagliptin with the fixed dose of 100mg once daily has the same efficacy as the DPP4 inhibitor saxagliptin with the fixed dose of 5mg once daily, in patients with type 2 diabetes and the renal function decline.

Abstract:
There is a dearth of evidence‐based approaches for the treatment of borderline personality disorder (BPD) that can also be widely disseminated. The objectives of this study were to evaluate the efficacy of self‐help BPD online treatment for nonborderline personality disorder symptoms in an internet‐based sample of adult internet users with high self‐reported online contact frequency and to explore whether the BPD self‐help program has an influence on BPD symptoms (i.e., borderline symptomatology) and depressive symptoms. A quasi‐experimental design and a repeated measures design were established by using an online questionnaire. Participants with low scores on the borderline personality disorder self‐report scale were included (N = 797). After the first assessment, participants were matched in terms of baseline values and then randomly assigned to either an intervention or control group. The control group received two follow‐ups after 2 and 6 weeks (total T2 T3 design). Participants in the intervention group and the control group completed an online intervention or an attention control group in parallel. After 2 and 6 weeks, follow‐ups were held. Participants' borderline symptomatology and depressive symptomatology were assessed over the course of the study. At these measurements, mixed linear longitudinal models were used to examine differences in depression and borderline symptoms between the four‐time points. The results showed that BPD users were significantly more affected by depressive symptomatology. There was no significant effect for the other measurements, but there was a general improvement in depression and borderline symptoms across the entire four measurement periods. No differences were found between the control group and the intervention group. Although the intervention resulted in fewer borderline symptoms in the intervention group, all participants profited from the intervention.

Abstract:
Background: This single‐center, randomized double‐blind trial investigated the effect of intradialytic hemodiafiltration (HDVHDF) supplemented with additional convective dose during acute kidney injury (AKI) on clinical outcomes. Methods: Thirty‐six patients with AKI on hemodialysis were randomized to receive HDF or HDVHDF supplemented with additional convective dose (HDF‐ADD). HDVHDF was defined as a 4 hour hemodialysis with a high‐flux membrane and added a convective dose of 10‐15 ml/kg per hour. Results: The mean age of the study patients was 69.0 ± 12.6 years old, and 18 were male (50.0%), while 18 had diabetes (50.0%). There were no significant differences between the baseline characteristics of the two treatment arms. The mortality rate was lower in the HDF‐ADD group [16.67% (95% CI: 0.38‐0.87)] than that of the control group [63.89% (95% CI: 16.23‐71.74)] (OR 0.26; 95% CI: 0.07‐0.96, p=0.041). Patients in the HDF‐ADD arm had better clearance of myoglobin/lactate dehydrogenase and a lower incidence of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome and hemoperitoneum (p=0.007, p=0.016, p<0.001, respectively). All patients in the HDF‐ADD group survived (0.00%) at discharge. Conclusion: Intradialytic HDF supplemented with additional convective dose (HDF‐ADD), compared with HDVHDF only, decreased the mortality rate significantly among patients with AKI on hemodialysis. Abstract:
Objective: The purpose of the study was to retrospectively determine the incidence of catheter‐associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) in the intensive care units (ICUs) of Glydon Medical Hospital in South West China after the use of different antibiotics with uretravertebral catheter. Design: The incidence and etiology of CAUTI were analyzed and risk factors and etiologies were compared between male and female patients. Results: In this study, the incidence of CAUTI in female ICU patients was significantly higher than in male ICU patients (p < 0.05). Logistic regression analysis indicated that intravenous catheterization and the patient's age are independent risk factors, but the presence of a urinary catheter is not. In addition, the bacterial species associated with male and female urinary tract infections are different, and the main bacteria of catheter‐associated urinary tract infection are related to different uropathogenic bacteria. Conclusion: This study showed risk factors for CAUTI in female patients are older age and catheterization, while the urinary canal pathogen in female patient with CAUTI is significantly higher than that in male patients, which needs to be paid close attention to clinical diagnosis and treatment as soon as possible.

Rehabilitation for patients suffering from unstable angina is an effective means of reducing mortality as well as morbidity. However, it seems to be underused. A lot of research has shown that a supervised inpatient cardiac rehabilitation program gives the best results. But many patients aren’t accepted  for this type of rehabilitation or find it difficult to attend it. The primary objective of the study is to evaluate the effects of a home-based cardiac rehabilitation program compared to supervised inpatient cardiac rehabilitation program for patients with unstable angina. The secondary objectives are to  evaluate the effects on health and well-being, medication  intake, and to evaluate the number of re-hospitalisations caused by cardiac reasons. The study is a mono-center double-arm trial where patients are randomised to one of two groups: home-based cardiac rehabilitation program compared to supervised inpatient cardiac rehabilitation program. Both groups will have to participate in a standardised education programme. Participants will undergo an ECG recording, blood sampling, anthropometric measurements and VO2 max will be measured. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The aim of this study is to explore the association between the serum inflammatory response and the early mortality rate in patients with high risk of cardiac disease.

Detailed Description
-----------------
Inflammation is involved in the pathophysiology of acute heart failure (AHF) and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). Several studies indicate the association between inflammatory response, cardiovascular biomarkers, and prognosis in AHF patients, but we still lack a comprehensive evaluation of the role of serum biomarkers in the short-term prognosis of AHF patients. This study is performed to evaluate the association between early changes in inflammatory response and the early mortality rate in patients with high risk of cardiac disease. For these aims, the researchers plan to conduct a prospective, longitudinal study. The primary endpoint will be a composite outcome of all-cause death or readmission within 30 days following index admission. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of all-cause death or cardiovascular death, heart failure hospitalization, and death within 30 days. The researchers hypothesize that inflammatory response will be elevated shortly after admission, and it might be associated with the adverse clinical outcome.

Official Title
-----------------
Association Between Serum Inflammatory Response and the Early Prognosis of Patients With High Risk of Cardiac Disease, a Prospective Longitudinal Study

Acute Heart Failure

Abstract:
The aim of this study was to analyze the association between plasma homocysteine (Hcy) and carotid intima‐media thickness (IMT) in healthy adults. A study population of 528 healthy adults who had Hcy and IMT measurements was selected by simple random sampling. The levels of L‐Lysine, L‐Arginine and S‐Adenosyl methionine (SAMe) were also determined. Participants were divided into three Hcy groups, according to quintiles of the mean plasma Hcy values. The relationships between plasma Hcy levels and carotid IMT were examined. We found that plasma Hcy was significantly associated with carotid IMT after adjustment for known traditional risk factors. Moreover, significant associations of plasma L‐Arginine and L‐Lysine levels with the mean values of carotid IMT were also seen in both genders. We also found a significant positive correlation between plasma SAMe to Hcy (SAMe/Hcy) levels and mean values of carotid IMT, which was significant only in males. Our findings may provide a potential link between plasma Hcy and carotid IMT in healthy adults and suggest that modulating plasma Hcy levels may be a novel approach to prevent or delay atherosclerosis in individuals within the general population.Copyright © 2016 Li et al. This is an open access article distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
This work is an applied research project that seeks to implement an individual counseling and exercise program that integrates yoga, based on a self-management program guided by positive psychoneurobiology and supported by a self-applied neuropsychological stress relief program. The study sample is made up of in vitro fertilization patients, after which they will receive a self-management program, where the main objective will be the training of the frontal cortex on a cognitive rehabilitation scheme in order to improve the ability to self-regulate emotions, the main strategy of the stress regulation system in the body. Cognitive rehabilitation is based on scientifically validated techniques, in vivo and based on neuroscience experiments, specifically in the field of neuropsychology and positive psychology, which include yoga. The yoga proposed in the research project is the laughter yoga, which is a non-physical exercise developed by an Indian doctor, Dr. Madan Kataria, as a result of his studies on stress, meditation, mental and physical therapy. This technique, together with the training proposed in an audiovisual format, form a self-applied program in which the patient is a key element in the success of cognitive rehabilitation. Specifically, the self-applied program consists of the use of video recordings, that is, the subjects, through the guidance of a psychologist specializing in cognitive therapy and clinical neuropsychologist will watch the videos with the aim of imitating and repeating the techniques and exercises proposed in each of them and finally incorporating them into their daily routine. The purpose of the video recordings is to adapt the techniques and exercises to the needs of the patient, thus improving the rate of inclusion in the rehabilitation program. The project will be carried out with the aim of evaluating the application of this psychoneurobiological approach to in vitro fertilization patients, analyzing the stress levels that may be linked to the experience, both in terms of physiological

Description:
=================
Brief summary in scientific language:
-----------------
Anxiety disorders in a pregnancy environment are described by various symptoms, for example, generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), in which the level of anxiety appears as unsteady or unsteady. These disorders have major health consequences; they can influence maternal outcomes and the child's health in turn. Although the number of people affected by mood disorders in pregnancy is high, anxiety symptoms in the first months of pregnancy are largely unreported and underdiagnosed. Pregnant women are often not offered evidence-based mental health care to prevent or alleviate symptoms. According to studies, psychotherapeutic programs based on Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) for pregnancy anxiety reduce anxiety in pregnant women. In addition to therapeutic measures, additional factors such as social support appear to play a particularly important role in the outcome of anxiety in pregnant women. This study aims to investigate the effect of laughter yoga on the stress levels of pregnant women suffering from pregnancy anxiety and to test its mechanisms of action. The hypotheses are that laughter yoga can lead to a reduction in levels of anxiety symptoms during pregnancy. Moreover, the intervention and the mechanisms of action are expected to be mediated by perceived relaxation.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a study to describe long-term clinical response from regorafenib treatment of patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) in the U.S (Unites States).

Detailed Description
-----------------
The purpose of this study is to describe the clinical outcomes of long-term treatments with regorafenib among patients with MCRC resistant to first line therapy or treatment failure in treatment-refractory MCRC and to obtain real world evidence (RWE). This study includes adult patients with mCRC who commenced treatment with regorafenib after the date of January 1, 2013, and the date of diagnosis of mCRC was from July 1, 2018, through Dec 31, 2022, in the ­US. The primary objective is to assess the proportion of mCRC patients who achieved 18-month or longer clinical stability (non-progression) from the date of first regorafenib treatment. The secondary objectives are to evaluate the clinical efficacy of regorafenib among patients with mCRC in the U.S. Additional objectives include evaluating outcomes based on patient, tumor and treatment characteristics, and evaluating outcomes when treating mCRC that remains responsive to fluoropyrimidine. Data will be collected from Flatiron's Oncology Electronic Data Network (EDN) using electronic health records (EHRs) for patients at participating sites. The data will include details related to regorafenib and other therapeutic agents, and clinical and radiology outcomes. The study results will be disseminated through posters, peer-reviewed journal publications, internal and external presentations such as symposia and national/international conferences. The study results will also be published on the Flatiron Health website and presented to external research organizations, patient advocacy groups, and the general public.

Background
-----------------
Despite a growing body of research on the benefits of exercise for individuals with ADHD, compliance with exercise-based interventions can be low. Technology-based solutions, such as gamified exercise programs, have the potential to enhance compliance and provide personalized feedback and support to individuals with ADHD. This study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a gamified exercise program combined with a smartwatch for individuals with ADHD.
The primary objective of this study is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a gamified exercise program combined with a smartwatch for individuals with ADHD
Research Questions
-----------------
1. What is the feasibility of implementing a gamified exercise program combined with a smartwatch for individuals with ADHD? 2. What is the acceptability of the program to participants? 3. What are the potential areas for improvement of the program and study design?
Methods
-----------------

Exclusion Criteria: Individuals who do not meet the inclusion criteria or have severe ADHD symptoms will be excluded. Outcomes: Feasibility will be assessed through the number of participants who drop out during the study, the number of participants who complete the intervention, and the number of participants who adhere to the exercise program. Acceptability will be assessed through survey data on the usability and acceptability of the intervention. Potential areas for improvement will be identified through participant feedback.

Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to compare the antihyperplastic and antiangiogenic effects of oral finasteride, dibutylstilbestrol, and tamoxifen in patients with prostate cancer. Eighty‐five subjects with histologically confirmed prostate cancer were divided into four groups (A, B, C, and D). Group A (prostate cancer 1) was not treated, group B (prostate cancer 2) was treated with finasteride (1 mg/day), group C (prostate cancer 3) was treated with finasteride (1 mg/day) and dibutylstilbestrol (1.5 mg/day), and group D (prostate cancer 4) was treated with finasteride (1 mg/day) and tamoxifen (20 mg/day). The results showed that serum prostate‐specific antigen (PSA) levels were significantly lower in prostate cancer 2, 3, and 4 than in prostate cancer 1. The prostatic volume in prostate cancer 2 was significantly lower than in prostate cancer 1. In prostate cancer 3 and 4, the prostatic volume, mean urinary flow rate (QMAX), and nocturia were similar to or slightly better than in group A. Furthermore, the levels of sex hormone‐binding globulin (SHBG) and the androgen to SHBG ratio were significantly lower in prostate cancer 3 than in group A, and significantly higher in prostate cancer 4 than in group A. In conclusion, the combination of finasteride and dibutylstilbestrol showed the best antihyperplastic and antiangiogenic effects in patients with prostate cancer.

Trial ID: DRKS000217992

Study Overview
=================

Official Scientific Title of the Trial
-----------------
Influence of a single dose of 30mg dexmedetomidine vs. 50mg propofol on emergence agitation in children after sevoflurane sevoflurane anaesthesia - a randomised clinical trial

Description
-----------------
The frequency of emergence agitation (EA) in paediatric patients after sevoflurane anaesthesia is still high. This is of relevance as EA may cause increased trauma risk, post-operative respiratory depression and delayed extubation, especially in younger children. Currently available prophylaxis is limited and usually based on benzodiazepines, which cause side effects such as sedation. A small clinical study found that single-dose propofol prophylaxis resulted in reduced incidence of EA compared to placebo in older children. No study investigated efficacy and safety of dexmedetomidine in children, however, numerous studies in adults suggest that dexmedetomidine might represent a favourable alternative prophylactic treatment, also in this patient population. Additionally, it is likely that the frequency of EA is related to the concentration of sevoflurane applied at emergence. The present study aims to investigate the influence of a single dose of 30 milligrams (mg) dexmedetomidine and 50 mg propofol on emergence agitation in children after sevoflurane anaesthesia. In a single-blinded, randomised clinical trial, the efficacy and safety of two different doses of dexmedetomidine (0.02 and 0.04 microgram/kg) compared to 50 mg propofol will be evaluated. The main outcome measure will be the occurrence of emergence agitation at 3 minutes (T3) after extubation.

Trial Type
-----------------
RCT

Trial Phase
-----------------
Phase-II-III

Purpose
-----------------
Treatment: Drugs

Background: Early goal‐directed therapy (EGDT) has been shown to improve survival in sepsis patients. However, the effect of empiric antibiotics before the clinical diagnosis of infection is not well established. Objectives: To evaluate the effect of early antibiotics (before the establishment of infection) on all cause 30‐day mortality in patients with sepsis or septic shock. Methods: The investigators screened prospectively enrolled and treated patients in the Temporal Targeting of Treatment in Sepsis and Septic Shock trial. They excluded any patients who were enrolled in the EGDT arm (those with a lactate ≥4 mmol/L (> 30 mg/dL) and a time from ED arrival to first antibiotic ≥120 minutes), and a subset of those who were enrolled in the initial control arm. These patients did not receive protocol‐based resuscitation to achieve hemodynamic goals. Rather, the treating physician was free to use their own judgment to choose treatments and resuscitation strategies. For this analysis, the investigators included those patients who fulfilled the sepsis‐3 criteria for infection within 24 hours of enrollment. In patients who did not show evidence of infection within 24 hours of enrollment, the investigators compared early antibiotic receipt (on ED arrival) vs. later administration (any time later than 2 hours after admission). The primary endpoint was all cause mortality at 30 days. To adjust for potential confounders, the investigators utilized propensity score matching in a 1:1 ratio using a greedy matching algorithm that maximizes the propensity score similarity. Results: 57.7% of the control patients did not have evidence of infection within 24 hours of enrollment. Among these patients, 49% were administered antibiotics within 2 hours of hospital arrival. Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
The investigators propose to study a new methodology for the treatment of acute non-traumatic cardiac arrest due to cardiac arrest from ventricular fibrillation. The investigators hypothesize that, on the basis of evidence gained from experimental and clinical studies, prompt use of antibiotics in acute myocardial infarction patients with cardiac arrest from ventricular fibrillation may lower myocardial reperfusion injury and improve outcomes. The investigators propose that by using a novel strategy, which may be characterized as an 'infarct-to-perfusion ratio' antibiotics may be administered prior to reperfusion, resulting in improved outcomes. The aim of this observational study is to determine whether a new strategy of treatment of acute non-traumatic cardiac arrest patient from ventricular fibrillation due to cardiac arrest, using infusing the patient with a combination of antibiotics prior to onset of resuscitation is feasible and safe.

The TEMPLACE-2 (Treatment of patients with a low chance of survival after 2 h of in-hospital cardiac arrest study) is a multicenter observational registry study aiming to register all patients who have suffered a non-traumatic Cardiac Arrest (CA) cardiac arrest that occurs in-hospital who are eligible for hypothermic body temperature. The primary study objective is to evaluate if the choice of target Body Temperature (bT) (low vs. normal) results in different primary out comes (ROSC within 4 hours, 30 day survival rate, Cerebral Performance Category (CPC) outcome and 1 year survival rate) for Cardiac Arrest patients with low likelihood of survival at 2 hours after CA defined as patients without circulation after 2 hours (i.e. without ROSC) that are eligible for hypothermic Body Temperature (BT) treatment. Secondary Objectives: * To describe the effect of bT on secondary outcomes (survival at discharge and Hospital Free Days at day 1, day 30 and day 180) * To describe the effect of bT on neurological outcome 1 year after randomization * To assess the effect of bT on myocardial reperfusion and ischemic time during CA * To assess if the patient, or their next of kin, experiences a benefit or harm (according to their rating of quality of life) after the patient has sustained a CA. * To explore the impact on mortality of different clinical characteristics in patients with non-traumatic cardiac arrest (CA) that occur in hospital. * To explore

Study Overview
=================

Brief Summary
-----------------
The overall goal is to determine whether the provision of the following in a self-care intervention, in persons with chronic low back pain, has efficacy in reducing pain, and reducing use of prescription opioids (PO) and physical therapy (PT): 1. Home-based exercise: Exercises to help increase trunk and hip muscle strength; 2. Electrical muscle stimulation (EMS): EMS delivered to the trunk and hip muscles with a small, wearable device; and 3. Nutritional supplement: Omega-3 fish oil (PO) capsules.

Detailed Description
-----------------
A two-arm parallel group randomized trial of 8 weeks duration using an active-comparator (control group) (1) and an experimental group (2). Both groups will be treated with the active-comparator (EMS + exercise + sham nutrition and usual care) and a group-specific intervention (EMS + exercise + fish oil and usual care), with the latter differing by intervention component. Hypothesis: Participants with chronic LBP receiving the active comparator (EMS + exercise + sham nutrition and usual care) will experience a reduction in pain and opioid use, as compared to participants receiving usual care alone. A participant's average pain over two weeks (primary outcome) will be assessed daily during the intervention period. Pain intensity, pain-related disability, self-reported opioid use (PO) and PT use will also be assessed.

Official Title
-----------------
Effects of an Intervention Based on Exercise, Electrical Muscle Stimulation, and Omega-3 on Chronic Low Back Pain: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Abstract:
The objective of the present study was to assess the effect of low dose interleukin‐2 (IL‐2) subcutaneous (SC) injection in combination with doxorubicin chemotherapy with respect to local regional and distant control of breast cancer, as well as overall survivability, and their impact in long‐term survival. Thirty patients completed the study in this randomized phase III trial in the Instituto do Câncer do Estado de São Paulo. Patients were randomly assigned on day 1 of doxorubicin treatment to receive either SC injection of recombinant human IL‐2 (rh2) 6 million IU after the third cycle of chemotherapy, or no rh2, as the control group. IL‐2 was administered in a 25 million IU dose, given every three hours at three different sites (arm, abdomen and buttock). Tumor size, number of lymph nodes, and pathological type were similar between the two groups at recruitment, and all patients received a total of six cycles of doxorubicin. After a median of 31 months of follow‐up, patients in the rh2 group showed a superior median relapse‐free survival (32.6 versus 24.9 months, respectively) and overall survival (not reached versus 48.5 months, respectively). There was a difference in regional nodal status between the two groups, with a higher number of regional events in the control group (ten versus three, P = 0.034). A small increase in cardiac events was also observed in the rh2 group (8 events in each group). These results suggest that the administration of rh2 after the third cycle of doxorubicin chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer may improve long‐term survival and regional control.

The present study aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of percutaneous adhesiolysis performed using a standard 5% hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)‐based solution with a 19% hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)‐based solution. Patients who underwent adhesiolysis from April 1, 2016 to March 31, 2018 were randomly and retrospectively allocated into two groups. Group A underwent adhesiolysis using a 5% H2O2‐based solution while group B underwent adhesiolysis using a 19% H2O2‐based solution. Group A included 82 patients and group B included 55 patients. We found that the total operating time was significantly longer in group A with a mean of 24.82±6.52 min compared to 19.33±4.36 min in group B (P=0.0001), and the operation duration was 58% greater in group A compared to group B. Intraoperative complications, such as mucosal injury and bowel perforation, occurred in the majority of patients in groups A and B (61.5%; P=0.759), with no significant differences observed (P=0.833). The time required for hospitalization in groups A and B was 9.13±2.54 days and 8.42±2.24 days, respectively. Furthermore, 28% of the patients in groups A and B received other therapeutic treatments following the procedures to address symptoms of gas‐liquid blockage (P=0.269). Our results suggest that 5% H2O2 is as effective as 19% H2O2 in adhesiolysis and can be used as an alternative to conventional 19% H2O2 in situations where higher hydrogen peroxide concentrations

Abstract:
Aim: To evaluate a self‐learning algorithm for the interpretation of high‐density lipoprotein cholesterol, apolipoprotein B and apolipoprotein A‐I cholesterol in the Nijmegen lipid research 2002 and the Lipids 1999 reference data sets: effects on the quality of prediction of coronary heart disease. Design, subjects and methods: Data sets from 943 men and 1074 women (2017 subjects) were randomly and independently divided in two, a learning subset (50%, 1009 subjects) and a testing subset (50%, 1008 subjects) by an external computer program blinded to the composition of the study. Linear regression analysis was performed for the determination of beta co‐efficients and standard errors. Receiver operator characteristics (ROC) were calculated for the discrimination of coronary heart disease (CHD) (disease present vs. disease absent) using the beta co‐efficients. Results and Conclusions: High reproducibility was observed for both self‐learning and conventional multiple linear regression analysis. In the total, ROC areas were larger in the self‐learning model (men: 0.74 vs. 0.67; women: 0.73 vs. 0.70). These differences were mainly attributed to the increased prediction for those men <60 years of age in the self‐learning model (ROC areas: 0.77 vs. 0.66).

Detailed Description

Background: Diverticular disease (DD) is the most common gastrointestinal disease in industrialised nations, with a prevalence of 51% of adults >50 years of age. It affects both sexes and is mainly attributed to the Western diet, although it may also be hereditary in some people. With aging, the prevalence of DD increases and is currently at approximately 70% among individuals over 80 years of age. DD consists of both an uncomplicated and a complicated course, which are referred to in the literature by different nomenclatures and with varying frequency. Acute diverticulitis is characterised by the clinical picture with systemic symptoms, fever, and inflammation of a segment of the intestine with an increase in the CRP concentration as well as the WBC count. Complicated diverticulitis refers to intra-abdominal abscesses or fistulas, obstruction, bleeding, or perforation of the intestinal wall, which can develop peritonitis, intestinal obstruction, intestinal ischemia or perforation. Mortality is 5-12%, and recurrent episodes of diverticular disease are present in 20-50% of patients. In most studies, the majority of patients have symptoms, such as abdominal pain, bloating, and constipation, in addition to clinical symptoms, without the condition necessarily becoming complicated. The diagnosis of complicated or acute diverticulitis is primarily based on clinical symptoms, ultrasound, and blood tests (CRP etc.), and is confirmed by colonoscopy. CT is also a diagnostic procedure but is not always necessary. Complicated

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
Chronic diverticular disease of the colon is a very common condition, defined as the presence of one or more diverticula in the large intestine. Patients with this disease can suffer from recurrent flare-ups of inflammation, which can lead to pain, fever, vomiting, diarrhea and other symptoms. The aim of this randomized, multi-center, open label, controlled trial is to compare the efficacy of two antibiotic regimens in treating patients with diverticulitis: 1-week course of moxifloxacin + metronidazole and 10-day course of ampicillin + amoxycillin + sulbactam. We hypothesize that a 7-day course of antibiotics with moxifloxacin and metronidazole will be equally effective in treating diverticulitis as a 10-day course of antibiotics with ampicillin, amoxycillin, and sulbactam in terms of symptom relief, resolution of inflammation and quality of life. Our study was approved by the local ethical review board. The primary outcome of this study is the resolution of inflammation, defined as a reduction of the C-reactive protein (CRP) level to <5 mg/L. Secondary outcomes include symptom resolution, quality of life, duration of hospital stay, number of adverse events, and antibiotic-associated side effects. Inclusion criteria are: men and women over 18 years of age with a diagnosis of acute uncomplicated diverticulitis of the sigmoid colon; CRP level >10 mg/L; an ability to understand and willingness to sign an informed consent form.

BACKGROUND: Previous reports have shown that anemia is associated with increased cardiovascular mortality in patients with heart failure (HF) and normal baseline hemoglobin (Hb) concentrations. Anemia has been shown to increase the risk of HF in hypertensive patients and increase the risk of death in patients with HF with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). However, the relationship between Hb concentrations and prognosis in patients with HF with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) remains controversial. Therefore, we aimed to investigate the relationship between baseline Hb concentrations and mortality in a large cohort of patients with HFpEF. METHODS: We enrolled 6496 patients with HFpEF from the National Heart, Blood, and Lung Institute Cardiovascular Disease Prevention Trial (PREVEND) population‐based cohort with left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) ≥ 50% and serum creatinine levels <2.0 mg/dL. BACKGROUND: To evaluate the effects of S‐1 adjuvant immunotherapy in patients with operable pancreatic adenocarcinoma.METHODS: In this open label, single center, randomized controlled phase II study, patients with a histologically confirmed pancreatic adenocarcinoma undergoing curative resection were randomized to the S‐1 adjuvant chemotherapy plus SAF313‐DX484 (n = 27) group after standard adjuvant therapy or the S‐1 with conventional therapy (n = 15) group.RESULTS: The 2 groups did not show any significant differences in the overall, progression‐free, or disease‐free survival. In the S‐1 with adjuvant chemotherapy group, only 2 of 27 participants had recurrence compared to 5 in the control group, and the recurrence rate and median recurrence‐free survival (RFS) were 7.4 and 16.2 months, respectively. The 2‐year recurrence rate was 63.6%. Survival analysis showed that overall, progression‐free, and disease‐free survival rates of the participants with recurrent pancreatic cancer in the S‐1 with SAF313‐DX484 group were prolonged compared to the control group. In particular, after excluding patients with metastatic disease (M), the recurrence‐free survival rate was significantly higher in the S‐1 with SAF313‐DX484 group compared to the control group.CONCLUSION: S‐1 adjuvant immunotherapy may prolong the RFS in pancreatic cancer patients without M.

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
This study is designed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the 1-year administration of inhaled recombinant human deoxynuclearase (rhDNase) in children and young adults with cystic fibrosis (CF) and non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis (NCFBE) with p.Phe508del homozygous or p.Gly178Arg mutant CFTR mutations with clinical evidence of chronic respiratory infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Clinical evidence of active infection is defined as a documented infection or a positive culture without the presence of an inhalation treatment for P. aeruginosa (IAI) within 3 months of the baseline visit. Approximately 40 sites in the United States and Canada will be enrolled into a pooled, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, 52-week (1-year) study in which participants receive 20 weeks (months 1-3) of blinded treatment (either 1800 U/kg rhDNase or placebo to be given according to body weight) followed by 32 weeks (months 4-9) of open-label treatment. RhDNase will be administered at the end of the blinded period to all participants. At week 52 (month 9), participants will undergo a comprehensive pulmonary function assessment and bacteriologic evaluation. After the week 52 visit, participants will complete six optional 14-28-day pulmonary interim assessments (PIA) until month 13. All participants must meet the following inclusion/exclusion criteria: 1) documented diagnosis of CF or NCFBE; 2) homozygous for the Phe508del or Gly178Arg mutation; and 3) demonstrated clinical evidence of chronic infection with P. aeruginosa. Participants also must meet specific age, radiology, pulmonary function testing, and antibiotic use criteria to participate in this study.

Abstract:
Introduction: The impact of acellular dermatology vaccines can vary widely. One contributing factor is the baseline burden of comorbidities. This study aimed to investigate the impact of the risk of mortality on the effectiveness of the acellular dermatologic vaccine, DER‐21 (Zostavax). Study design: We included 8,892 patients who received one dose of DER‐21, and the patient had at least three consecutive visits after dosing. Patients who received live zoster vaccine were excluded. Efficacy of DER‐21 was assessed as the prevention of herpes zoster (HZ) and postherpetic neuralgia. The efficacy of DER‐21 was analyzed using Cox proportional hazards models, adjusted for age, sex, and site. Statistical analysis was carried out using SAS and R. Results: Out of the 8,892 patients in the analysis, 34 died during the follow‐up period (mean, 3.3 years; median, 2.9 years), mostly due to the underlying disease. Patients who died had a significantly higher risk of HZ (Risk ratio [RR]: 3.65; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 1.85, 7.20; P=0.0002) and postherpetic neuralgia (RR: 3.83; 95% CI: 1.84, 8.03; P=0.0004) compared with surviving patients. Cox models were used to assess the relationship between efficacy and risk of mortality. The dose of the Background Treatment during this period will be as per local practice, with the possible exception of 20% reduction in background therapy doses. Randomization into one of the two arms of the study will depend on the subject's background treatment status. Subjects not treated with background therapy, or not tolerating it, or in whom no effective background therapy can be identified, will be randomized into placebo treatment Arm. Subjects who continue to receive background therapy will be randomized into the sotatercept treatment Arm.The study population will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive one of two potential treatments, Sotatercept or Placebo. Each subject will receive either 240 mg of sotatercept by subcutaneous injection once every 4 weeks, or no intervention, per protocol for 48 weeks.

Abstract:
The authors present a pilot study to evaluate the immunocontraceptive efficacy and pharmacokinetics of a 20‐month dosing regimen of the conjugate vaccine Choc1 against chlamydia pneumoniae in women. Thirty‐six previously‐unexposed women and thirty‐six sexually‐active women without recent seroconversion received the three injections at monthly intervals, with follow‐up for 20 months. Women in the study were from the general population and received no contraceptive instructions. No adverse reactions to the vaccine were reported. Seroconversion to choc1 was detected in five of eight women when tested 20 months after completion of the injections. Five women had persistent antibody titers. Of the 36 nonreponders, only one developed a chlamydia pneumoniae infection. Twenty‐four of 30 sexually active women developed chlamydia pneumoniae infections during the period of observation. These data suggest that protection by Choc1 requires longer than a 20‐month dosing interval.

Study Overview

Brief Summary
-----------------
This is a pilot study of a new treatment for wet macular degeneration (wet AMD), a common and complex eye disorder. It has been estimated that approximately 11 million people in the United States live with the condition, which causes patients to lose their central vision as it gets worse over time. The study will determine whether combining two treatments that stimulate the body's own healing can improve a patient's vision. Over 12 months, the study will evaluate a novel device to deliver controlled pulses of electrical current to stimulate healing and a nutrient-infused eye drop to supplement cells and support them to produce healing proteins.

Title

Effectiveness of a Resistance- and Aerobic-Based Exercise Intervention to Reduce Fatigue and Improve Quality of Life in Patients With Advanced HIV 

Scientific title
=================
Randomised controlled trial of a supervised exercise training programme on fatigue and quality of life in persons with advanced HIV

Plain English Summary
=================
Background and study aimsIn recent decades, there have been major advances in the treatment of infection with the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV), which is the virus that causes AIDS. As a result of these advances, life expectancy for people living with HIV has increased significantly, with many patients surviving for many more years. Currently it is common for people living with HIV to use many different types of therapies including anti-viral medications and to be taking these therapies long-term. These developments have increased the number of people living with HIV who have long-term health conditions or diseases that cause more than one disease (often termed co-morbidities, or ‘co-morbs’). Co-morbs can include diseases of the cardiovascular, renal, gastrointestinal, neurological, and bone systems, as well as obesity and type 2 diabetes. Patients with HIV not only need to manage their HIV infection, but also their co-morbs. One major problem faced by patients living with HIV is fatigue. This is a symptom, or group of symptoms, caused by one or more diseases and is a common condition in those with HIV, estimated to affect up to 70% of people diagnosed. Symptoms of fatigue include tiredness or lack of energy, and can impact a person’s ability to perform activities of daily living and their quality of life (or how they perceive their life to be). Currently there are no established, evidence-based treatment options for reducing fatigue in people with HIV. The aim of this study is to assess the effectiveness of a supervised aerobic and resistance exercise intervention to reduce fatigue and improve quality of life in adults with advanced HIV compared with a control condition (standard of care). Who can participate?People over 18 years of age, living with HIV and fat

Intervention
=================
Blood sampling (non-interventional)

Brief summary
=================
Evaluation of biochemical and haematological variables during sedation in patients with moderate to severe acute respiratory distress syndrome who required intubation and mechanical ventilation during an ICU stay. The study will specifically examine the changes in biochemical markers, such as troponin and white blood cell count, and haematological parameters during the course of the ventilation. The study will also investigate the relationship between these changes and patient outcomes, such as ICU and hospital length of stay, mortality, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) outcomes. The results of the study will contribute to a better understanding of the effects of prolonged sedation on the body's biochemical and haematological parameters and help to improve the management of patients with ARDS during the ICU stay.

Abstract:
This study investigated the role of hypoxia in modifying the response of human skin to histamine‐induced irritation, using laser Doppler flowmetry (LDF) as a monitoring tool. Five different doses of histamine were administered to ten male volunteers on six separate occasions; on one occasion, they were also subjected to hypoxemia prior to histamine, on another, to hyperoxemia, and on the remaining four occasions no treatment was given (sham treatment group). All parameters were measured after an equilibration period of five minutes using LDF‐derived blood flow measurements. Hypoxia caused a decrease in peripheral resistance in cutaneous vessels and this was accompanied by a dose‐dependent increase in blood flow upon histamine administration, whereas hyperoxemia prevented the increase in blood flow without any change in peripheral vascular resistance. The mean change in blood flow from the sham treatment was significantly higher in the hypoxemic group than in the hyperoxemic and sham treatment groups. These results suggest that alteration of arterial oxygen content causes a change in the irritant response of human skin.

Study on the Prevalence and Epidemiology of Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD), Intermittent Claudication, and Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) in CKD Patients

Study Overview
=================
Brief Summary
-----------------
Patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) have increased odds of acute vascular complications, such as acute limb ischemia and limb amputation. The prevalence of PAD has been reportedly increasing over the past few years and the trend is most pronounced at lower extremities (PAD). Although patients with CKD are at increased risk for PAD, currently there are no large studies available on prevalence and severity of PAD in general and CKD population in a specific manner. In addition, the impact of CKD on the prognosis of patients with PAD has not been well-defined in the literature. Thus, a retrospective observational study will be conducted to obtain data on ABI tests in patients with CKD of whom at least 50% will be CKD patients with PAD. The investigators' study will focus on peripheral arterial disease (PAD), intermittent claudication, and ankle-brachial index (ABI) in CKD patients. Primary aims are: To estimate the actual prevalence of PAD in CKD population To analyze the relationship between eGFR and ABI To analyze the prevalence and severity of PAD by type of chronic kidney disease (CKD), its etiology, and stage of CKD To investigate
